headline: Allegheny Energy Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2010
componenttextpreview: The 36 terawatt-hours, I know in your script, you talk about having done a dispatch model to get comfortable with that, but I can't recall the last time that your fleet actually ever got to that level of output. So I think there's a little bit of trepidat
componenttext: The 36 terawatt-hours, I know in your script, you talk about having done a dispatch model to get comfortable with that, but I can't recall the last time that your fleet actually ever got to that level of output. So I think there's a little bit of trepidation amongst investors this morning that, that's an aggressive assumption, can you give us some comfort as to why we should feel that, that's achievable?

headline: Allegheny Energy Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, Greg, what happens there is that the function of power -- it's a function of two things, it's a function of the power price that we expect to realize and it's a function of the dispatch costs. So if you think back, 2008 was a pretty strong year on po
componenttext: Yes, Greg, what happens there is that the function of power -- it's a function of two things, it's a function of the power price that we expect to realize and it's a function of the dispatch costs. So if you think back, 2008 was a pretty strong year on power price, but we had coal piles that were running down, so we put in a higher replacement. We don't bid our accounting cost for coal. So we bid in a higher economic value for the coal in 2008. And emissions costs were higher as well. Then you get to 2009, and we were bidding in more aggressive and lower cost, something much closer to what our accounting costs are. But power prices were very low. And in fact, too low to even dispatch on occasion. And now, you get to 2010, and power prices are up a bit, but we're also projecting the dispatch at lower cost for a number of reasons. Some of it is coal, some of it's emissions, some of it's the way we've adjusted some of the derating of the plants. So we have a little bit slower dispatch cost and a little bit higher expected realized price, then that's would results basically and output being up.

headline: Allegheny Energy Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2010
componenttextpreview: And Greg, by the way, in 2006, we had close to 38 million megawatt-hours. 2007 was 35 million, 2008 was like 34.5 million. So we've been at that level, we're pretty close to it in some prior periods.
componenttext: And Greg, by the way, in 2006, we had close to 38 million megawatt-hours. 2007 was 35 million, 2008 was like 34.5 million. So we've been at that level, we're pretty close to it in some prior periods.

headline: Allegheny Energy Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2010
componenttextpreview: You inferred on the transmission front, notwithstanding the deferral of construction on PATH, that there's $400 million to $600 million of potential other projects that could be spent over the next several years that's not in the current budget, is that c
componenttext: You inferred on the transmission front, notwithstanding the deferral of construction on PATH, that there's $400 million to $600 million of potential other projects that could be spent over the next several years that's not in the current budget, is that correct, and could you elaborate on that? And what would be the method for getting that sort of firmed up and into earnings?

headline: Allegheny Energy Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2010
componenttextpreview: It's about to $600 million to $900 million, is our preliminary estimate in projects that we spent in the period 2011 to 2014. And they mostly -- they would dress reliability and replace aging infrastructure. They're really are in two buckets. One bucket i
componenttext: It's about to $600 million to $900 million, is our preliminary estimate in projects that we spent in the period 2011 to 2014. And they mostly -- they would dress reliability and replace aging infrastructure. They're really are in two buckets. One bucket is what we think, from our preliminary discussions with PJM, that they will be ordering us to build, that's about half of it. These are non-backbone-type projects. And to the extent that bucket happens, it'll probably be done by our transmission company recovered through the same kind of formula rates. The other half is existing infrastructure within our own AP system, likely to be constructed again by the regulated utility.

headline: Allegheny Energy Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2010
componenttextpreview: At what point do you think you'll be giving us an update on whether those projects are going to be go forward? Is there going to be sort a lot of little projects, or is it going to be some one big sort of announcement from PJM, how do we think of that?
componenttext: At what point do you think you'll be giving us an update on whether those projects are going to be go forward? Is there going to be sort a lot of little projects, or is it going to be some one big sort of announcement from PJM, how do we think of that?

headline: Allegheny Energy Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well I think PJM process, as they get approved, will announce them, and the next time will be June of this year. And the other ones, we'll have to start working on. And we also would like to have the same kind of recovery at the state level for the second
componenttext: Well I think PJM process, as they get approved, will announce them, and the next time will be June of this year. And the other ones, we'll have to start working on. And we also would like to have the same kind of recovery at the state level for the second batch of investments that we have for FERC. So I think we'll be going particularly to Pennsylvania to try to get through some kind of the comparable cost-recovery formula rates, before we start launching into that spending. But we thought we should make you aware of what the opportunity may be in transmission within our own existing footprint.

headline: Allegheny Energy Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2010
componenttextpreview: So the bad news is PATH has gotten indeterminate delay but there's other projects that might slot in, in front of PATH that could still be earnings-accretive.
componenttext: So the bad news is PATH has gotten indeterminate delay but there's other projects that might slot in, in front of PATH that could still be earnings-accretive.

headline: Allegheny Energy Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, and I don't like that word indeterminate. I mean these determinations coming out of the PJM are a TEP process, which is really a very comprehensive process. They complete it every June, annually. In June of '09, they said PATH had to be ready by 2014
componenttext: Yes, and I don't like that word indeterminate. I mean these determinations coming out of the PJM are a TEP process, which is really a very comprehensive process. They complete it every June, annually. In June of '09, they said PATH had to be ready by 2014. They obviously haven't done the June 10 one. But the issue came in Virginia where the staff started saying well, give us you latest update to your comprehensive process. Demand's been coming down or extended out, demand responses there, what do you think's going to happen? And the estimate that PJM made at that time was that it looked like it'll pushed out, which it may well. We don't know if it's a year or two or longer. But I think what it really needs is that full comprehensive review. So we'd expect and hope that coming out of that June process, we'll be able to say definitively when PATH would be constructed. Because these aren't things you just kind of turn on and off, as you know.

So there's $20 million tax, $33 million everything else, leading to the $53 million that's embedded in this year's last half of the year income.

headline: Allegheny Energy Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2010
componenttextpreview: And I want to touch on Greg's question just a little bit on the generation output. Was your output historically -- because, Paul, you referenced some levels of output in '07 and '08. Was that weighed down by some of the environmental works, so the numbers
componenttext: And I want to touch on Greg's question just a little bit on the generation output. Was your output historically -- because, Paul, you referenced some levels of output in '07 and '08. Was that weighed down by some of the environmental works, so the numbers would have actually -- if I go back I think the '08 number was like 34.5 million megawatt hours from some of your key units, really your coal units. Was that weighed down at all by the environmental work so that number would have been higher in '08 had the scrubber work not been underway?

headline: Allegheny Energy Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2010
componenttextpreview: No, I don't think there was a big impact from that. I think it really is more that we try to use an economic dispatch approach. So we don't bid in the coal at the weighted average cost of which we've acquired the coal. We try to bid it in at what the mark
componenttext: No, I don't think there was a big impact from that. I think it really is more that we try to use an economic dispatch approach. So we don't bid in the coal at the weighted average cost of which we've acquired the coal. We try to bid it in at what the market value is for coal and emissions and other things. And we were using higher costs back in that time. And if you think back in 2008, our coal piles were going down, and forecasts for coal prices were going up. So we were using a higher value for the coal that we priced into the dispatch. And that's really what drives it.

headline: Allegheny Energy Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2010
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from Reza Hatefi of Decade Capital.
componenttext: The next question comes from Reza Hatefi of Decade Capital.

headline: Allegheny Energy Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2010
componenttextpreview: I guess your '11 and '12 hedges ended up being a little lighter than your goals had been as far as percentage hedged level. Can you talk about I guess why it ended up a little lower or what's the process and strategy there?
componenttext: I guess your '11 and '12 hedges ended up being a little lighter than your goals had been as far as percentage hedged level. Can you talk about I guess why it ended up a little lower or what's the process and strategy there?

headline: Allegheny Energy Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, it was kind of at the low end of the range. I mean it was within the range, but clearly the low end of the range. And we just thought there's more opportunity for upside in prices that was in that broad range that we have that would come in at the l
componenttext: Well, it was kind of at the low end of the range. I mean it was within the range, but clearly the low end of the range. And we just thought there's more opportunity for upside in prices that was in that broad range that we have that would come in at the low end. That's where the judgment came in. I mean we set targets, percentage targets. And within that range, we do exercise a little of our own judgment on whether we want to be at the high end or the low end. And our sense is we want to be at the low end for a while.

headline: Allegheny Energy Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2010
componenttextpreview: And just a follow up to Greg Gordon's question earlier, the generation volumes for 2010 through 2012, I guess they also increased pretty materially, about couple of terawatt-hours versus your disclosure in the third quarter presentation. What caused kind
componenttext: And just a follow up to Greg Gordon's question earlier, the generation volumes for 2010 through 2012, I guess they also increased pretty materially, about couple of terawatt-hours versus your disclosure in the third quarter presentation. What caused kind of the quick or I guess the swift increase in expectations for generation in just the last three months or so?

headline: Allegheny Energy Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, it's the same phenomenon that causes it if you go back and look at the historical numbers. Basically what's happened since we did the last call is that the forecasted price we received for power went up by about $1, and the average cost to produce we
componenttext: Yes, it's the same phenomenon that causes it if you go back and look at the historical numbers. Basically what's happened since we did the last call is that the forecasted price we received for power went up by about $1, and the average cost to produce went down by about $2 per megawatt hour. So you factor that in and your plants get dispatched  more often.

headline: Allegheny Energy Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2010
componenttextpreview: And it seemed like your coal hedged prices also went down $1 or $2. Is this just because of special adjustments in some of these contracts or...
componenttext: And it seemed like your coal hedged prices also went down $1 or $2. Is this just because of special adjustments in some of these contracts or...

headline: Allegheny Energy Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2010
componenttextpreview: It's basically the escalators in the contracts. Those contracts have some cost escalation in them. And we use different econometric projections to try to estimate what those are going to be. So those are our estimates of what those costs will be now going
componenttext: It's basically the escalators in the contracts. Those contracts have some cost escalation in them. And we use different econometric projections to try to estimate what those are going to be. So those are our estimates of what those costs will be now going forward.

headline: Allegheny Energy Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2010

componenttext: These hedged goal prices include transportation of like $8 to $10 or something like that?

componenttext: Yes, they include transportation, which you could say on average would be around $8 to $10.

headline: Allegheny Energy Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2010

componenttext: Paul, you mentioned that internally, you're on the low end of the hedging portion because you exercise the prerogative to assume those on the upside. How much are we talking about in terms -- I'm assuming it's relative to the fourth quarter. How much optimism do you have for '11 and '12 above that forward curve?

headline: Allegheny Energy Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2010
componenttextpreview: I wouldn't want to pick a number, Lasan. I mean it's just a feeling that the economy has seen some really tough flows. And I think the forwards are based off of the kind of the troughs that we're at. Although they show a little improvement in PJM West, bu
componenttext: I wouldn't want to pick a number, Lasan. I mean it's just a feeling that the economy has seen some really tough flows. And I think the forwards are based off of the kind of the troughs that we're at. Although they show a little improvement in PJM West, but I mean not heck of a lot. And it's kind of just an evaluation or an expectation that if things pick up, we'll do well and very well. And on an unhedged basis, we got 36 million-megawatt hours out there. So every buck means something. It's just basically a judgment. We think there's more up than down from what the forwards are saying. Now we're only doing that within the context of this range that we have. So we're not betting a ranch on prices going up by any stretch.

componenttext: Coal-to-gas? It's kind of hard to quantify that. We can tell you that our gas plants dispatch quite a bit more during the quarter than what you might typically see, but we can't. I think in the back of the earnings release, we have some capacity factor information. If you go to the second to the last page of the press release, you can see our supercritical capacity factor was like 58%, down from 78% in the prior year. And if you look at gas, you can see that the gas -- we only have the capacity factor but you can see the gas output. It's 321,000 megawatt-hours versus 44,000 in the prior period, up over 600%. So clearly, there's some gas displacement of coal. And as prices move up and gas prices move up, which the forwards implied they will do next year, we would expect to see a lot of that turn around.

headline: Allegheny Energy Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, we have. We filed last year and we had a hearing date set for March of this year before the State Corporation Commission. The staff retained a special consultant to advise them. And you might have seen last week or so, they issued a report that raise
componenttext: Yes, we have. We filed last year and we had a hearing date set for March of this year before the State Corporation Commission. The staff retained a special consultant to advise them. And you might have seen last week or so, they issued a report that raised certain questions and issues about rates of customers post-June 11. And the co-ops, I think, have addressed a lot of the concerns expressed in the reports. There were really, I think, some inaccuracies in that report. And I think we and the co-ops both feel that this is going to be beneficial to our customers. So we're still both expecting a successful conclusion and an approval by the commission sometime shortly after their March hearings. So probably sometime by the end of the second quarter.

componenttext: Not offsetting anything in '09. It's really a timing issue. You're basically just booking a big deferred tax. So in 2010, we will make up for as far back as we can go on this accounting change. There'll be a big impact in '10, and then kind of unwind over time going forward.

headline: Allegheny Energy Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2010
componenttextpreview: Paul, going back to West Virginia, on the whole issue of whether you can get relief for taxes or not. Given your own change in your overall corporate tax rate now that you know the cash tax bid in '10. I know that theoretically that would have nothing to
componenttext: Paul, going back to West Virginia, on the whole issue of whether you can get relief for taxes or not. Given your own change in your overall corporate tax rate now that you know the cash tax bid in '10. I know that theoretically that would have nothing to do with West Virginia. But given the last time they ruled against you for that very reason that you're not a cash taxpayer or the parent, do you feel that that makes your hand more difficult now as you're dealing with this rate case this time around?

headline: Allegheny Energy Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, it would make it more difficult than if we didn't have that item. I mean how we distinguish this item from the prior is a special one-time kind of adjustment. It's almost like restatement of taxes where you -- that's the cumulative impact of those ca
componenttext: Yes, it would make it more difficult than if we didn't have that item. I mean how we distinguish this item from the prior is a special one-time kind of adjustment. It's almost like restatement of taxes where you -- that's the cumulative impact of those capitalized repairs. So commissions ought normally to look at normalized items and normalized tax liabilities. So we're hoping they kind of see through this item. And if they normalized it, then we'd be back to the position we were when we filed a case, namely that we would be paying tax. Now that's the logic. As you say, whether they'll look at it that way, I don't know. We're hopeful but we'll see.  But clearly, it makes it more difficult that we're not paying tax. Although we're quite happy not to pay tax.

componenttext: Well, we constantly look at that kind of trade-off, Lasan. componenttext: You've had a lot of questions on the terawatt-hours of generation volume. And I guess the question is what your view is given that a lot of your competitors have also guided to fairly healthy volumes, return to healthy generation volumes in 2010. But some of the utilities' actual loads in terms of the guidance hasn't been as robust. And thus, there seems to be a mismatch between a lot of generators' expectations for volume versus the coming back of utility load. I guess could you talk about that phenomenon? And is there differentiation between maybe your generation versus maybe some of your competitors in PJM? Or how should we think about that?

headline: Allegheny Energy Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, I guess the way I think about it is -- you're basically asking a question on is the forward market wrong. I mean we're taking forward power prices, which take into account what the market expects the supply and demand situation to look like. So if t
componenttext: Well, I guess the way I think about it is -- you're basically asking a question on is the forward market wrong. I mean we're taking forward power prices, which take into account what the market expects the supply and demand situation to look like. So if the forward market is wrong and the prices that we're seeing in the forward market are too high, and they actually come in lower than what we expect, then our output would be lower as would all the other generators who I'm sure run models very similar to what we run.

headline: Allegheny Energy Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2010
componenttextpreview: Is overall demand a part of the equation? Or how does that sort of get formulated?
componenttext: Is overall demand a part of the equation? Or how does that sort of get formulated?

headline: Allegheny Energy Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2010
componenttextpreview: The demand is reflected in the expectations for forward power prices. So if demand were expected to be -- if we weren't in this economy and demand were expected to be stronger, then I would expect power prices to be higher. And if demand is expected to de
componenttext: The demand is reflected in the expectations for forward power prices. So if demand were expected to be -- if we weren't in this economy and demand were expected to be stronger, then I would expect power prices to be higher. And if demand is expected to decline, I will expect power prices, all the other things being equal, to decline as well. And that'll affect our dispatch.

headline: Allegheny Energy Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2010
componenttextpreview: Reza, I'd add one other item. I mean most of us use the same industry-tested dispatch model. And it's conceivable the model might miss some things in this kind of down-and-up process that we've been through. It's been a unique process the last year throug
componenttext: Reza, I'd add one other item. I mean most of us use the same industry-tested dispatch model. And it's conceivable the model might miss some things in this kind of down-and-up process that we've been through. It's been a unique process the last year through the economy and the recovery, et cetera. So if we're all using the same model and it's all telling us the same thing, we'll see. Maybe there's a quirk in the dispatch model. I wouldn't say that's an impossibility by any stretch.

headline: Allegheny Energy Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2010
componenttextpreview: Although we've back tested ours, and it's worked pretty well.
componenttext: Although we've back tested ours, and it's worked pretty well.

componenttext: Hello. This is the Chorus Call conference specialist. Welcome to the Allegheny Energy First Quarter 2010 Financial Results Conference Call. headline: Allegheny Energy Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May 05, 2010
componenttextpreview: Good afternoon, everyone, and thanks for joining us. If you have to leave the call before it's over, you can listen to the taped replay. It's available until midnight on May 14, and you can listen to it by telephone, on our webcast or by podcast.Some of
componenttext:
Good afternoon, everyone, and thanks for joining us. If you have to leave the call before it's over, you can listen to the taped replay. It's available until midnight on May 14, and you can listen to it by telephone, on our webcast or by podcast.
Some of our statements will be forward looking. These statements involve risks and uncertainties, and are based on currently-available information. Actual results may differ significantly from the results and the outlook we discuss today. Please refer to our earnings news release and our SEC filings regarding factors that may cause actual results to differ from the forward-looking statements made on this call. 
Our presentation includes some non-GAAP financial measures. On our website, you'll find the reconciliations required under the SEC's Regulation G. After our prepared remarks, we'll take your questions. We ask that you try to limit your questions to two each, so we have time to get to as many of you as possible.  And now let me introduce Paul Evanson, Chairman, President and Chief Executive Officer of Allegheny Energy.

headline: Allegheny Energy Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May 05, 2010
componenttextpreview: Good afternoon, everyone, and I'd like to thank all of you for joining us today. Today, we reported that adjusted earnings, excluding costs related to our proposed merger with FirstEnergy and unrealized losses on hedges, were $103 million or $0.61 per sha
componenttext:
Good afternoon, everyone, and I'd like to thank all of you for joining us today. Today, we reported that adjusted earnings, excluding costs related to our proposed merger with FirstEnergy and unrealized losses on hedges, were $103 million or $0.61 per share. 
Both our Merchant Generation and Regulated Operations  earned a solid profit, but earnings were down due to storm-related costs. 
The snowstorms that struck our territory in early February required the largest service restoration in the company's history. Nearly one out of every three of our customers lost power, and this cost us nearly $30 million pretax or about $0.11 per share. 
Turning aside the storm costs, our regulated operations had a good quarter, due in large part to higher revenues from our transmission expansion. Retail sales were up 2.3%, the first year-over-year increase in megawatt-hour sales in two years. Sales to industrial customers were up even more, increasing almost 6% versus the same period last year. We're pleased to see these signs of an economic recovery. 
In the Merchant Generation segment, our supercritical plant availability and capacity factors improved over the first quarter of last year. However, the segment reported a decrease in net income, due in large part to interest and depreciation on the new scrubbers at the Hatfield plant. 
The continuing decline in power prices was largely offset by our hedges. We're now 87% hedged for 2010, 47% in 2011 and 16% in 2012, all of which are consistent with the targets we've communicated in the past. That is, by the end of a given year, we want to have hedged 80% to 90% of next year's output, 30% to 50% of year two and 0% to 30% of year three. 
We remained on track for a smooth transition to market base rates in Pennsylvania, where our rate caps expire at the end of this year. Our regulated business has already contracted for 2/3 of the power needed to serve residential customers and nearly 50% to serve small and medium commercial and industrial customers for the full year 2011. The next option to procure generation will be held later this month and results should be announced by May 21. And another auction for a substantially larger block will be held in October.
Turning now to other priorities for the year. The 500-kilovolt Trans-Allegheny Interstate Line, or TrAIL, remains on schedule for in-service in June 2011. Nearly 60% of the towers have been constructed and about 20% of the wire has been installed. In mid-April, we energized a new Pennsylvania 502 Junction substation where TrAIL will interconnect with several existing transmission lines. 
Regarding our second transmission project, the Potomac-Appalachian Transmission Highline, or PATH, PJM is expected to announce the revised in-service date at the completion of its Regional Transmission Expansion Planning or RTEP process in June. On the sale of the Virginia distribution territory, we reached a settlement agreement with most of the parties last week. The original contract price of the sale was approximately $340 million, and we agreed to contribute $62.5 million over a four-year period to help reduce rates for customers. The settlement still requires approval by the Virginia Commission, and we now expect the closing by the middle of the year. 
In West Virginia, we also reached a settlement agreement with the staff, consumer advocate and other parties for a base rate increase of $60 million, $40 million of which will be effective on June 29 of this year and the balance of $20 million will be effective on June 1, 2011. Also, our current rates for fuel and purchased power cost recovery will decrease on January 1, 2011 by $20 million. But this amount will be recovered in future filings, so there's no impact on earnings. We expect the Public Service Commission to issue an order on the settlement by the end of June.
In other regulatory developments, we are re-evaluating our plan in Pennsylvania that emphasize the installation of smart meters to meet the energy conservation and demand management requirements of Act 129. Our original plan necessitated significant expenditures associated with advanced metering and its related customer information systems. 
As part of the merger integration process, we have been looking at FirstEnergy's Act 129 plan, which was recently approved by the commission and which relies much less on smart meters in the early years. We now hope to develop a less-costly program that will still allow us to meet the necessary reductions. This remains a work in progress.  Of course, our top priority for the year is to work towards approval for the merger we announced with FirstEnergy in early February. This merger should significantly enhance value for Allegheny shareholders. 
First, our shareholders will receive a significant premium, more than 30% based on the stock prices of both companies when the merger was announced. And shareholders will receive a dividend increase of almost 150% based on FirstEnergy's current dividend payout.  Second, and very importantly, combining with FirstEnergy will diversify our fuel mix by adding significant nuclear capacity, something we couldn't have done on our own given our size and capabilities. And furthermore, the combination with FirstEnergy provides greater operational scale and scope. 
Our contiguous service territories make a perfect fit. We'll be a major player in distribution, transmission and generation, with 24,000 megawatts of generating capacity, most of which merchant. With increased size should come increased efficiencies of all kinds. Also, we expect the combined company will have a solid balance sheet and strong operating cash flows. It will have the financial strength and capital to invest in core business initiatives and growth opportunities, and the company will retain upside leverage to a future increase in power prices. 
As for the approval process, the preliminary S-4 Registration Statement has been filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission. Special shareholder meetings through each company are likely to take place in the third quarter. This month, we should be filing for approval with the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission, followed by filings in Pennsylvania, West Virginia and Maryland and then later in Virginia. Based on this timetable, we expect to complete the merger sometime in the first half of 2011. 
While we work on the filing, the integration teams from both companies have kicked off their efforts, and FirstEnergy's CEO Tony Alexander and I have been visiting stakeholders throughout our service territories. These meetings have generally been positive and constructive. 
As with any transaction of this kind, however, issues will emerge along the way, but I'm confident we can work through those issues and bring the merger to a successful completion. Until then, we continue to operate our business as usual, that is, focusing on our core generation and regulated operations and executing on our goals and objectives for the year. In doing that, we'll keep the fundamental drivers of our long-term value intact and remain positioned for strong growth in the future.  Now let me turn the call over to Kirk.

headline: Allegheny Energy Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May 05, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Paul, and good afternoon, everyone. As Paul has already discussed, adjusted earnings for the first quarter were $0.61 per share as compared to $0.67 per share for the first quarter of last year. This is not adjusted for the effect of February s
componenttext:
Thank you, Paul, and good afternoon, everyone. As Paul has already discussed, adjusted earnings for the first quarter were $0.61 per share as compared to $0.67 per share for the first quarter of last year. This is not adjusted for the effect of February storms, which reduced 2010 earnings by $0.11 per share. Adjusted earnings exclude net unrealized losses associated with hedging activities and $13 million of expense associated with the proposed merger with FirstEnergy. 
Adjusted pretax earnings decreased by $34 million in the first quarter compared to the same period last year. EBITDA for merchant generation was flat compared to the first quarter last year. Unhedged net revenue decreased but was offset by an improvement in our power hedge margin. You'll find details in the Appendix, but let me give you an overview of what drove these items.
Unhedged net revenue decreased by $15 million due to lower realized prices and higher fuel expense, which was partially offset by an increase in capacity revenue. Our power hedge margin improved by $16 million. Power hedge margin compares the average contract price on our hedges to the current period cost of serving those contracts, including the cost of energy, capacity, ancillary services and congestion. 
Regulated operations benefited from the continued progress on our transmission expansion projects, and as Paul has mentioned, the increase in load, which we've seen across all customer classes. However, these benefits were offset by the increased operating costs we incurred for restoration efforts during the February storms. We expensed $29 million for storm a restoration costs this quarter versus $9 million in the first quarter of last year. As a point of reference, our storm costs historically have averaged around $14 million per year. 
Operating expenses included a non-recurring charge of $10 million related to employee benefits. This charge affected both segments. Both interest and depreciation expense were consistent with our expectations. Interest expense for the entire company was higher by $20 million. About $11 million was due to the fact that we stopped capitalizing interest cost on certain projects that went into service in 2009, principally the Hatfield Scrubber Project. Another $6 million relates to financing for transmission expansion, which is recovered in rates. Depreciation expense increased by $11 million, primarily due to the Hatfield and Fort Martin scrubbers being placed in service. 
Moving on to the next slide, our effective tax rate improved for the quarter due to the $9.5 million charge that we took in 2009 for a change in the valuation of our Pennsylvania net operating loss carryforward.  Cash flow from operations excluding merger costs was $185 million. This was a $178 million improvement over the first quarter of 2009, where we were negatively impacted by changes in collateral obligations, coal inventories and West Virginia deferred energy costs. 
Capital expenditures were $268 million. Free cash flow, netting the securitization proceeds used to fund the Fort Martin scrubbers and financing for TrAIL, was a positive $5 million for the quarter. In aggregate, our current liquidity including cash on hand totals more than $2 billion. 
There are no remaining debt maturities in 2010 except for securitization and amortizations. We've completed several financings this year to better align the capital structure to the individual businesses. Notably, TrAILCo received an investment-grade rating and refinanced its construction credit facility by issuing medium-term notes and entering into a new credit facility.
Now let's turn to the outlook. This slide summarizes our most recent estimate of the changes from last year in EBITDA for each of the businesses and for consolidated depreciation and interest expense. We'll now go through the drivers of each of these line items.
Moving to Slide 32, for Merchant Generation, we estimate a $55 million decrease in 2010 EBITDA, which is a $46 million decrease from our estimate on the last call. Our estimates are based on, among other things, forward power prices at March 31, 2010. 
For the full year 2010, we are using a PJM Western Hub energy price of $40 per megawatt-hour, which is a combination of three months actual and nine months of forwards. You may recall that on our last call, our estimates were based on forward prices of $48 per megawatt-hour for 2010.  The decrease in our projected merchant generation result is consistent with the downward price trend for commodities. 
Forward prices are subject to highly-variable market factors outside of our control, and our estimates will continue to change due to fluctuations in those prices and other factors. Since our last call, the decrease in forward energy prices has resulted in a projected decline in unhedged energy margin of $220 million and resulted in an increase in power hedge margin of $178 million.
Turning to Slide 33, we are expecting to generate 7 million more megawatt hours than in 2009. However, the contribution to unhedged energy margin from these additional megawatt hours is low. 
Total expense includes the cost of both contracted coal and our small open position. We are estimating an increase in other fuel-related costs, primarily due to a full year of operation of the Hatfield scrubbers, offset by a decrease in natural gas expense.  $56 million increase in capacity reflects a $25 per megawatt day increase in capacity prices. 
Operating expenses, primarily O&M and state and local taxes will increase by about $10 million. 
So in summary, our unhedged EBITDA is better by $44 million primarily due to an increase in capacity revenues, partially offset by increased operating costs. Adjusted EBITDA is calculated on Slide 34 by starting with the unhedged EBITDA from the prior slide and adjusting for the impact of our power hedge position. These hedges include financial hedges, our West Penn Power contract, which expires at year-end 2010 and other marketing contracts. 
Projected margin contribution of our hedges is expected to contract versus 2009. Please note that the average contract price and contract market value include energy, capacity, ancillary services and congestion. Our contract market value represents the estimated cost to serve or replacement costs of these contracts as of March 31, 2010. 
Finally, for the Merchant Generation business, we also provide additional information in the Appendix on Slides 47 through 54. These slides contain additional data for analyzing the business, some high-level pretax income sensitivities and information on hedging activity that has occurred post March 31.
Moving on to Slide 35, utility operations. Please remember that we are including the Regulated Generation business of Mon Power in these results. EBITDA for utility operations is expected to grow by $4 million. This is $54 million worse than our estimate on the last call. The West Virginia rate case driver reflects the results of our recent settlement, which is yet to be approved by the West Virginia Commission. 
Our West Virginia settlement provides for a $40 million annualized rate increase effective June 29, 2010 and an additional $20 million increase in base rates effective January 1, 2011. As a result, if the settlement is approved, we'll see a $20 million increase in EBITDA due to rate increases in 2010 and an additional $40 million increase in 2011, for a total increase of $60 million annually. 
As part of the settlement, we will defer recovery of $20 million of deferred energy costs from 2011 to 2012. This complement of the settlement does not affect earnings in either year. 
As stated earlier, operations and our maintenance expense increased by $20 million to restore service after the February snowstorms. Our West Virginia rate settlement includes recovery of the West Virginia portion of the first quarter storms. A net benefit for this recovery of $5 million will be reflected in 2010 O&M expense. 
Recovery of securitized interest and depreciation related to the Fort Martin scrubbers and the remaining West Penn securitization is being reflected at the EBITDA level. While this benefits EBITDA, it does not affect earnings because they are offsetting impacts in depreciation and interest. 
As Paul discussed, we are evaluating a less-costly compliance program for Pennsylvania Act 129. Accordingly, we have slowed down spending and have eliminated the projected $10 million benefit. 
Finally, we have assumed here that the Virginia asset sale closes in June of 2010 instead of April, which would reduce EBITDA from ongoing operations by $24 million. There will also be offsetting effects of the sale on depreciation, interest and income tax expense.
Slide 38 shows estimated growth in rate base for utility operations. Please note that these are estimates only and our plants are always subject to change. Until we have finalized our plan, we will continue to reflect Pennsylvania Act 129 expenditures that were included in our original filing. 
We've also included $275 million, primarily in the out-years in transmission projects approved through the PJM RTEP process and continue to work with PJM on identifying additional projects. We intend to pursue FERC formulaic treatment for these transmission investments and expanded state regulatory approvals for pass-through of FERC transmission rates. 
In 2010, Transmission Expansion EBITDA should more than double. TrAIL is expected to be in service in mid-2011. We are increasing our estimated capital expenditures for the TrAIL project by $75 million to $925 million. PJM has not yet furnished us with a revised in-service date for PATH. We are now projecting Allegheny's share of spending for the Transmission Expansion business to be about $480 million in 2010.  Rate base in our Transmission Expansion business is expected to grow to over $2 billion by 2014. With TrAIL and PATH, we earn a return in this business as capital expenditures are made. 
In addition to the increase in TrAIL capital of $75 million, rate base has also increased as a result of $115 million in additional PJM-approved RTEP projects that will be constructed in our Transmission Expansion business. For purposes of this forecast, PATH is assumed to be in service in 2016.
At the consolidated level, depreciation expense will increase by $46 million in 2010, due primarily to the scrubbers going into service in 2009. Fort Martin scrubbers will increase depreciation expense but will not affect earnings because this expense is recovered through a surcharge. 
The outlook for capital expenditures is reflected on Slide 42. Spending in the Merchant Generation business is expected to decline now that we have completed the Hatfield scrubbers. Also included here are the originally-filed amounts for Pennsylvania Act 129 capital costs, which we've covered, and the additional $390 million of PJM RTEP projects that I mentioned earlier.
Moving back to the income statement. 2010 current estimated interest expense is $49 million worse than 2009. This total is virtually unchanged from our February call. Interest expense changes for Transmission Expansion will not affect earnings because it is recovered in formula rates. The Hatfield scrubbers have been placed in service and interest that was previously being capitalized will now be expensed. 
Finally, while not reflected here, we expect our effective tax rate in 2010 to be about the same as or 2009 rate, which was 38%. With that, I'll turn the call over to the operator for questions.

componenttext: I wanted to ask you about the merchant drivers that you guys have on Slide 51, I think it is. And I guess I was sort of wondering what you guys are -- what's going on there with respect to your -- I know that the terawatt-hour have changed as well, but I guess what I'm trying to figure out is are you guys locking in power in 2011, 2012 when the prices don't seem that good? I mean, how should we think about that in terms of your expectation for a turnaround in the market, and it's not huge, but you guys do seem that you're increasing some contracts?

componenttext: Well, what we're doing is we've laid out certain hedge targets that we will try to hit, and we try to be somewhat agnostic as to price. And as long as we're locking in a reasonable margin, we target certain hedged percentages, and that's what we're doing here.

headline: Allegheny Energy Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May 05, 2010
componenttextpreview: With basis, it's really difficult to see exactly what's driving that. And it's typically transmission congestion, and it can be forward commodity prices in the two different zones. Also, some of what might be happening here is that with TrAIL coming onlin
componenttext: With basis, it's really difficult to see exactly what's driving that. And it's typically transmission congestion, and it can be forward commodity prices in the two different zones. Also, some of what might be happening here is that with TrAIL coming online in 2011 and the expectation for TrAIL coming online, that could result in basis expectations being lower in the out-years and then it could be sustainable.

headline: Allegheny Energy Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May 05, 2010
componenttextpreview: Paul, you mentioned and you highlighted the timeline for your various filings on the regulatory front coming up. I was just wondering, anecdotally, as you've obviously been in discussions or had conversations across your jurisdictions, any initial reactio
componenttext: Paul, you mentioned and you highlighted the timeline for your various filings on the regulatory front coming up. I was just wondering, anecdotally, as you've obviously been in discussions or had conversations across your jurisdictions, any initial reaction or sense that you get? Is it all, "Wait for the filing and then we'll talk?" Or any sense you can share on how the merger is being perceived in your key jurisdictions?

headline: Allegheny Energy Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May 05, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, as I mentioned, Tony [Anthony Alexander] and I have gone and visited all number of people in all of those jurisdictions. The discussions at this point have been very positive and constructive. Let's say the area where you get the most questions is,
componenttext: Well, as I mentioned, Tony [Anthony Alexander] and I have gone and visited all number of people in all of those jurisdictions. The discussions at this point have been very positive and constructive. Let's say the area where you get the most questions is, obviously, jobs and particularly in this kind of economy. But I think it's a little premature to know how the reaction's going to be when we finally file. It's looking good right now, but we'll see. I'm sure legitimate issues and concerns will arise, but it's probably too early to say what they'll be. But I think overall, I'm feeling pretty good with how the process has been going.

headline: Allegheny Energy Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May 05, 2010
componenttextpreview: The power commodity cost, obviously, have come down as reflected in your numbers as well. But I was just curious, are you seeing any signs of life or any positive data points that would make you somewhat more bullish on the merchant side versus a couple o
componenttext: The power commodity cost, obviously, have come down as reflected in your numbers as well. But I was just curious, are you seeing any signs of life or any positive data points that would make you somewhat more bullish on the merchant side versus a couple of months back?

headline: Allegheny Energy Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May 05, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, I think we started to see recovery in the Delivery business and Usage, particularly in the industrial side. We were up 6% over the first quarter year ago. It's still below where we were two years ago, the absolute level. But I think those are very e
componenttext: Well, I think we started to see recovery in the Delivery business and Usage, particularly in the industrial side. We were up 6% over the first quarter year ago. It's still below where we were two years ago, the absolute level. But I think those are very encouraging signs of the kind of a nascent recovery in manufacturing and industry in the Midwest area.

headline: Allegheny Energy Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May 05, 2010
componenttextpreview: The PJM auction, obviously, is underway. Any sense on what we should be expecting there? Any expectations of particular improvement from the last result?
componenttext: The PJM auction, obviously, is underway. Any sense on what we should be expecting there? Any expectations of particular improvement from the last result?

headline: Allegheny Energy Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May 05, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, we're within kind of days of getting the results for that so I'm kind of reluctant to pick a number or estimate what I think it'll be. I mean, there are some new things that have happened. Obviously, the coal number is different, that Susquehanna or
componenttext: Well, we're within kind of days of getting the results for that so I'm kind of reluctant to pick a number or estimate what I think it'll be. I mean, there are some new things that have happened. Obviously, the coal number is different, that Susquehanna or kV [ph] line is not included. FirstEnergy is in. Probably the biggest response or change is in demand response, that now the demand response has to bid in a price. Formerly, they just were required to be price takers, they bid in zero. So there is several variance in there that, overall, suggests to me that prices should be going up. But given that we'll find out in two weeks, I'd rather just wait and we'll all see what it is, Ali.

headline: Allegheny Energy Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May 05, 2010

headline: Allegheny Energy Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May 05, 2010
componenttextpreview: Wanted to ask about, I guess more on Slide 51. Comparing that to your last call, you had the forecasted or estimated power volumes that were going to be sold, and it looks like they've all basically declined. And for the 2010 numbers, is that decline most
componenttext: Wanted to ask about, I guess more on Slide 51. Comparing that to your last call, you had the forecasted or estimated power volumes that were going to be sold, and it looks like they've all basically declined. And for the 2010 numbers, is that decline mostly because of forward power prices for the rest of the year? Or is that some of that also from the first quarter, that the generation did not quite meet what you were expecting?

headline: Allegheny Energy Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May 05, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes. We were down some in the first quarter, which is -- it's also in here how much we were down in the first quarter. So some of it was first quarter, from what we expected we were down, and then some of it is also the balance of the year. And this is pr
componenttext: Yes. We were down some in the first quarter, which is -- it's also in here how much we were down in the first quarter. So some of it was first quarter, from what we expected we were down, and then some of it is also the balance of the year. And this is primarily being driven by the decline in forward power prices.

headline: Allegheny Energy Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May 05, 2010
componenttextpreview: And is there anyway that we can get a feel? I know this was a big discussion on your last call about how sustainable those numbers were based on the forward curve. Like if power prices were to go down $2 in megawatt-hours or something that that might impa
componenttext: And is there anyway that we can get a feel? I know this was a big discussion on your last call about how sustainable those numbers were based on the forward curve. Like if power prices were to go down $2 in megawatt-hours or something that that might impact the generation volumes by a certain amount or. . .

headline: Allegheny Energy Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May 05, 2010
componenttextpreview: The way I would think about that is the volume -- if you think about the volume changes, those are megawatts that are on the margins. So the marginal contribution of those incremental megawatt-hours either up or down when prices change are pretty small. T
componenttext: The way I would think about that is the volume -- if you think about the volume changes, those are megawatts that are on the margins. So the marginal contribution of those incremental megawatt-hours either up or down when prices change are pretty small. The bigger impact is price because it's the megawatt-hours that are further in the money, that you see the real margin increase or decrease when price changes. And I guess the best way to try to think about it is you could almost go look at the PJM supply curve and try to think about how a change in volume might impact a move along that supply curve. But I think the most important thing to keep in mind is it's really more driven by price than by volume.

headline: Allegheny Energy Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May 05, 2010
componenttextpreview: And you mentioned a $14 million, I guess, average storm -- was that the annual cost that typically -- so you had this was a $30 million storm, which you've only gone through a quarter of the year? It's totally blowing away your average, or was that sort o
componenttext: And you mentioned a $14 million, I guess, average storm -- was that the annual cost that typically -- so you had this was a $30 million storm, which you've only gone through a quarter of the year? It's totally blowing away your average, or was that sort of a first quarter type number?

headline: Allegheny Energy Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May 05, 2010
componenttextpreview: No, that was a yearly average. This storm was the worst storm we've had in the history of the company.
componenttext: No, that was a yearly average. This storm was the worst storm we've had in the history of the company.

componenttext: Just the realized energy, market sensitivities on Slide 53, those went down a little bit compared to last year. Is that all just because of the hedges that you've put in?

headline: Allegheny Energy Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May 05, 2010

componenttext: The next question comes from Jeff Coviello of Duquesne Capital.

headline: Allegheny Energy Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May 05, 2010
componenttextpreview: I had some questions around the longer-term coal contracts that you guys have previously disclosed. I know in the past when we've had run-up in prices in the coal markets, some of those contracts have been subject to renegotiation in terms of the price. I
componenttext: I had some questions around the longer-term coal contracts that you guys have previously disclosed. I know in the past when we've had run-up in prices in the coal markets, some of those contracts have been subject to renegotiation in terms of the price. I was wondering if, I guess, if any of that's going on now? Or if that's possible to occur in the future if coal prices stay strong? And I guess the kind of secondary question is with the recent mine accidents. I know the MSHA [Mine Safety & Health Administration] has been increasing oversight of the mines and that's likely to lead to more mine costs. And even if the contracts aren't renegotiated, you expect some inflation in the prices just due to the cost of mining?

headline: Allegheny Energy Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May 05, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, let me just start with the Massey tragedy. Obviously, we don't buy coal from that mine, it's Central App. And it could affect coal prices, generally, to the extent steam coal gets diverted perhaps into the met coal market. And it just suggests it co
componenttext: Well, let me just start with the Massey tragedy. Obviously, we don't buy coal from that mine, it's Central App. And it could affect coal prices, generally, to the extent steam coal gets diverted perhaps into the met coal market. And it just suggests it could have an impact on us in terms of cost because of new safety rules, whether enforcement or just brand new rules. But some of our contracts already have provisions that have pass-through for those cost and others don't. I'd say we had a lot of discussion with coal contractors when prices really spiked upwards or downwards. But I think, lately, it's kind of more settle down so I don't think we have a lot of really significant issues today on it, but in any event can always happen.

componenttext: Well, when you look -- I mean, most of the western coal is just strip mine, it's not underground mine. When you come east, it's kind of a percentage. componenttext: Well, back then, when you have a huge spike in prices, somehow people that have contracts that deliver at much, much lower prices find something to say, "Hey, maybe I don't have to deliver at these low prices when I could sell at a $30 a ton more." headline: Allegheny Energy Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May 05, 2010
componenttextpreview: I know it doesn't move the needle as much for you guys, but kind of a longer-term market question that can affect capacity markets a little bit, how do you see the tightening environmental standards across a variety of pollutants from the EPA combined wit
componenttext: I know it doesn't move the needle as much for you guys, but kind of a longer-term market question that can affect capacity markets a little bit, how do you see the tightening environmental standards across a variety of pollutants from the EPA combined with the upward pressure on thermal coal, combined with obviously the dark spread pressure with weak forward power prices, impacting subcritical units? I mean, do you think at a certain point, we start to see a mass retirement? Or is this still years, years down the road?

headline: Allegheny Energy Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May 05, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, I think it's going to be a gradual process. I don't think you'll see one day when all of them shut down or many of them. So it's going to be a gradual process, and it's going to be reflective of environmental rules probably first and foremost. And I
componenttext: Well, I think it's going to be a gradual process. I don't think you'll see one day when all of them shut down or many of them. So it's going to be a gradual process, and it's going to be reflective of environmental rules probably first and foremost. And I think that will -- and carbon legislation can certainly have an effective if that goes in and how it works. And some of the plants are just old plants. It's not that they can not only not comply with CO2, the cost of putting scrubbers and other things in it are just so much that if faced with having to do that, some of them may start shutting down, I think. So when that happens, obviously there's going to be a tightening within the whole supply-demand within the region, and there's a lot of subcritical megawatts within the PJM region. So I think longer term, it's perhaps a major driver of tightening of that capacity market.

headline: Allegheny Energy Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May 05, 2010
componenttextpreview: In your own situation, could do you see any decisions in the next couple of years? Or do you think it's longer term?
componenttext: In your own situation, could do you see any decisions in the next couple of years? Or do you think it's longer term?

headline: Allegheny Energy Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May 05, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think on some plants, we could see it in the next few years. I mean, we have one that's a classic. I mean, I love to visit it because it reminds me of a 1940s movie set. But it's the Rivesville plant down in West Virginia where it was opened 1945 or 194
componenttext: I think on some plants, we could see it in the next few years. I mean, we have one that's a classic. I mean, I love to visit it because it reminds me of a 1940s movie set. But it's the Rivesville plant down in West Virginia where it was opened 1945 or 1947, and it's a very small capacity. And what keeps it alive basically is the capacity payments today. But if faced with environmental rules, it could easily shut down. So that's on our hit list of things, it's one we're looking at. We have some subcriticals, but half of them are in regulated rate base, half unregulated. So there's really a different set of considerations applicable to each.

componenttext: I'm kind of a little confused about the Virginia sale. Originally the agreement was signed for $340 million and then after discussion, it looks like you're going to rebate about $30 million right off the bat on your pricing. Maybe I'm being too Machiavellian, but was there any reference to the merger with FirstEnergy when you were negotiating that price discount?

headline: Allegheny Energy Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May 05, 2010
componenttextpreview: I would say that it was perhaps in the backs of the minds of ourselves and the commission and others. I mean, it obviously has to be taken into account or considered. But I think the issue was even before the merger was announced because we had this enter
componenttext: I would say that it was perhaps in the backs of the minds of ourselves and the commission and others. I mean, it obviously has to be taken into account or considered. But I think the issue was even before the merger was announced because we had this entered into this last year, the staff particularly thought a premium of $125 million on $250 million of rate base was a big premium. And they didn't like the idea that we were getting it and leaving the state and had much rather have seen it all go to customers. So that was kind of part of the pushback from the staff and from customers, obviously, because they want to ensure that they have low rates for a long time. And as you know, we kind of pride ourselves on having low rates throughout our system. So that was a little bit of a push-pull with the merger, over time, being in the background, and was basically when you look at it, giving up have the premium. Because as you say, $35 million came off the purchase price immediately that [indiscernible] to the benefit of the co-op customers. And then another $27.5 million over the next three years or so, four years, will go to our own customers that we had served in Virginia. So it's taking half of the premium, it split the premium in half. We still walk away with a $62.5 million premium, which is you'd have to say pretty good, and some might consider it pretty good for regulated sale.

componenttext: On PATH, what do you think is going to determine the timing of the construction? Is it just because of reserve margins estimates or more because of the difficulty of actually getting the authorizations? And I was wondering if you thought that the two-year delay was optimistic?

headline: Allegheny Energy Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May 05, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, the delay in PATH -- well, the determination of when PATH is needed in any particular year is done by PJM, and they have a separate transmission group that that's really what they focus on. And what they focus on, really, first, foremost and almost
componenttext: Well, the delay in PATH -- well, the determination of when PATH is needed in any particular year is done by PJM, and they have a separate transmission group that that's really what they focus on. And what they focus on, really, first, foremost and almost in every way, is reliability, and when their violations of their reliability standards. So they look at that the earliest moment and try to make sure it gets in before that moment is net. And the economic conditions changed dramatically from two years or so ago, two and a half years ago, when it was first proposed, which has led to the delay. But we are looking forward to what their conclusion will be in June of this year. My own guess, it's my own personal guess is they'll probably see a need in maybe 2015 or perhaps 2016. But that's my guess, it has to be done on their very thorough, very complex analysis.

componenttext: Again, it's just really hard to tell, Ivana, what's driving the basis. It can be a single point time, transmission congestion can drive it out for some period of time, and then it comes back in. But this is an average number. It could be differences in commodity prices. It's really hard for us to tell what's driving the basis. We can give you an answer, but we don't know what's causing it necessarily.

componenttextpreview: Just following up on some of the earlier discussion on the coal contracts. And last time we went through this cycle, I remember going over in detail with Phil Goulding that you guys effectively got these long-term contracts by sort of contracting with sma
componenttext: Just following up on some of the earlier discussion on the coal contracts. And last time we went through this cycle, I remember going over in detail with Phil Goulding that you guys effectively got these long-term contracts by sort of contracting with smaller mines, largely. And so you sort of assumed, if I recall, agreed to give credit risk for a lot of NPV on price. Are these mines that you buy from, are they right on the cusp of being, as Phil would say, upside down on their cost structure relative to the price? Or is there a substantial amount of headroom in their cost structure still relative to the price at which they sell, and then there isn't really sort of looming upward pressure in the cost structure? And then related to that, how are these contracts defined under the merger agreement? And given their economic materiality, are they company-material contracts underwriting Section 325 of the merger agreement, or are they not? Just trying to figure out -- basically, they look like they're a major asset for the company. I'm trying to figure out if that asset is intact or if we're going to have it eroded like we did a little bit last time? And how it fits with the merger?

headline: Allegheny Energy Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May 05, 2010
componenttextpreview: I would say the strategy that we had was generally, as you articulated, although we also shifted a bit to smaller, even shorter-term, contracts from mines near some of our plants. And I think that's where we realized a lot of value, too, so it kind of cam
componenttext: I would say the strategy that we had was generally, as you articulated, although we also shifted a bit to smaller, even shorter-term, contracts from mines near some of our plants. And I think that's where we realized a lot of value, too, so it kind of came from both sides. Some of those contracts are still there, some of them still have some -- it kind of varies. Some, I think, have quite a bit of headroom, others are a little bit tighter. So I wouldn't want to generalize one way or the other, other than to say we're pleased with our contract. They certainly don't have the same economic value we thought we had when coal prices were much, much higher, for sure. So that's kind of the general answer. On the defined contracts, it's really -- I wouldn't want to get into that kind of thing on the call. As I indicated earlier, there are all kinds of provisions in that contract and the merger agreement and I just -- in the scheme of things, I doubt pressure on one or two contracts, or even a legal issue on one or two contracts, is a major issue relative to the consummation of this merger.
