Good afternoon and welcome to the Allegheny Energy second quarter 2010 financial results conference call. All participants will be in a listen-only mode. After todayâ€™s presentation, there will be an opportunity to ask questions. Please note this event is being recorded.
I would now like to turn the conference over to Mr. Max Kuniansky, Executive Director, Investor Relations and Corporate Communications. Sir, please go ahead.

headline: Allegheny Energy Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-04-2010
componenttextpreview: Good afternoon, everyone, and thanks for joining us. If you have to leave the call before itâ€™s over, you can listen to the taped replay. You can listen to the replay by telephone, on our Web site, or by podcast and weâ€™ll make it available through Augu
componenttext:
Good afternoon, everyone, and thanks for joining us. If you have to leave the call before itâ€™s over, you can listen to the taped replay. You can listen to the replay by telephone, on our Web site, or by podcast and weâ€™ll make it available through August 11.
Some of our statements will be forward-looking. These statements involve risks and uncertainties, and are based on currently available information. Actual results may differ significantly from the results and the outlook we discuss today.
Please refer to our earnings news release and our SEC filings regarding factors that may cause actual results to differ from the forward-looking statements made on this call. Our presentation includes some non-GAAP financial measures. On our Web site, youâ€™ll find the reconciliations required under the SECâ€™s Regulation G.
After our prepared remarks, we will take your questions and we do ask that you try to limit your questions to two each, so we have time to get to as many of you as possible.
And now let me introduce Paul Evanson, Chairman, President and Chief Executive Officer of Allegheny Energy.

headline: Allegheny Energy Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-04-2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Max, and good afternoon, everyone, and thanks for joining us. Today, we reported adjusted earnings of $0.57 per share for the second quarter, up substantially from $0.41 a year ago. These results exclude costs related to our proposed merger with F
componenttext:
Thanks, Max, and good afternoon, everyone, and thanks for joining us. Today, we reported adjusted earnings of $0.57 per share for the second quarter, up substantially from $0.41 a year ago. These results exclude costs related to our proposed merger with FirstEnergy, unrealized losses on hedges and a $45 million gain on the sale of our Virginia territory.
A number of factors affected our results but a major factor was lower operations and maintenance expense. These lower costs were primarily due to timing of special maintenance expenses at the merchant power plants. Such costs were down $34 million in the quarter over the prior year period. We had less than one week of planned outages in this quarter compared to 21 weeks in same period last year, when we were doing maintenance at three supercritical plants.
Results in the second quarter also benefited from a 41% increase in Merchant Generation output reflecting the fewer planned outages, higher power crisis and stronger demand. The capacity factor of the supercriticals was back to a more normal 76% in the quarter. The higher revenues were partially offset by the roll off of favorable power hedges.
In our regulated business overall sales were up 3.5% in the second quarter this year. Industrial sales increased 9% continuing the trend that we saw in the first quarter. These figures exclude sales in Virginia. We completed the sale of our Virginia distribution operations on June 1 of this year.
In addition, we reversed $9 million of West Virginia storm costs booked in the first quarter because of the favorable commission ruling. Finally, earnings from our transmission projects benefited results in the quarter.
Now looking at key areas of focus for the year, weâ€™ve made good progress on our top priority completing the merger with FirstEnergy. On July 16, the Securities and Exchange Commission declared our registration statement effective and we mailed our proxy material. A special meeting to approve the merger is set for September 14. FirstEnergy will also hold its shareholder meeting at the same day.
In addition, weâ€™ve filed all required applications for regulatory approval, both federal and state. Procedural schedules are now in place in all jurisdictions. As you would expect with the merger of this size and scope, a number of parties have intervened in the proceedings.
Based on the schedules, we think itâ€™s reasonable to expect decisions in Virginia as early as September from the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission in the fourth quarter, and in Pennsylvania, Maryland and West Virginia in the first quarter of next year.
Turning now to our other priorities, we remain on track for a smooth transition to market-bases rates in Pennsylvania, where rate caps expire at the end of this year. Our regulated business has contracted about 70% of the power needed to serve residential and small and medium commercial and industrial customers for the full year 2011.
Based on the contracts in place and assuming future prices are similar to the most recent auction, average monthly residential electric bills would only increase 4%, while small commercial and industrial bills would actually decrease by 2%. The next auction will be held in October and is heavily weighted toward commercial and industrial load.
Moving now to our transmission projects, the 500-kV Trans-Allegheny Interstate Line or TrAIL remains on schedule for in-service in June 2011. Right-of-way acquisition and substation construction are nearly complete. 83% of the towers have been constructed and 48% of the wire has been installed.
Regarding our second transmission project, the 765-kV Potomac-Appalachian Transmission Highline or PATH, in June PJM reaffirmed the need for the project and set the new in-service date for June 1, 2015.This confirmation is a major step forward for the project.
Weâ€™ve already begun to reengage the state regulatory approval process. Weâ€™ve made additional regulatory filings in Maryland and weâ€™ll re-file in Virginia, where we withdrew our application last year. In West Virginia, we anticipate a decision in May 2011.
Weâ€™ve also revisited the budget for the project since itâ€™s been three year since we first put it together. With increases in the cost of materials and services as well as new government agency requirements, we now estimate Allegheny share of the revised PATH budget as $1.4 billion, thatâ€™s up $200 million from the original estimate.
Another accomplishment during the second quarter was the regulatory approval of our West Virginia base rate case. The first phase, a $40 million increase went into effect on June 29. In the second phase, a 20 million increase will go into effect in January.
In other developments, Allegheny Energy Supply recently won power supply contracts in Maryland and Pennsylvania, and has entered into some commercial and industrial marketing contracts. As a result, we are now 89% hedged for the remainder of 2010, 59% in 2011, 23% in 2012, and 5% in 2013.
All of which is consistent with the targets weâ€™ve communicated in the past, that is by the end of a given year we want to have hedged 80% to 90% of the next yearâ€™s output, 30% to 50% of year two and 0% to 30% of year three.
The capacity auction for 2013, â€˜14 was held in mid-May. The clearing price was $28 per megawatt day in our region, an increase over the previous auction but still well below results of prior years and well below whatâ€™s needed to stimulate new investment.
On the environmental front, Allegheny is reviewing the impact of the Clean Air Transport Rule that the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency proposed in early July. The new rule substantially replaces the Clean Air Interstate Rule that a Federal Court overturned. The rule imposes state-by-state limits for sulfur dioxide and NOx emissions and restricts interstate trading, thereby limiting our ability to trade emission allowances to comply.
Itâ€™s also a different approach in Washington to proposed climate change legislation. When it became clear, an economy-wide Carbon bill did not have sufficient support in the Senate; utilityâ€™s only versions began to be discussed, that is the bill would regulate greenhouse gases for the utility industry only. It seems unlikely that even this limited version will be enacted this year.
Finally, Iâ€™m happy to report that Allegheny won second place in the American Society for Qualityâ€™s 2010 international team competition. More than 400 applicants worldwide competed on how they have used the quality process to improve operations.
The Allegheny team reported on a project that improved order fulfillment within supply chain. To finish second is really quite an accomplishment. Improving quality of service and reducing costs, thatâ€™s what I call high performance.
So to summarize, while we continue to face a tough economy, we are making solid progress on meeting our goal and objectives for the year. While working hard to complete our merger with FirstEnergy, we remain focused on our core business, especially controlling costs and looking for value-added opportunities.
Now, let me turn the call over to Kirk.

headline: Allegheny Energy Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-04-2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Paul, and good afternoon, everyone. As Paul has already discussed, adjusted earnings for the second quarter were $0.57 per share as compared to $0.41 per share for the second quarter of last year.Adjusted earnings for the quarter exclude net
componenttext:
Thank you, Paul, and good afternoon, everyone. As Paul has already discussed, adjusted earnings for the second quarter were $0.57 per share as compared to $0.41 per share for the second quarter of last year.
Adjusted earnings for the quarter exclude net unrealized losses associated with hedging activities, expenses associated with the proposed merger with FirstEnergy, and the $45 million gain from the sale of our Virginia distribution business.
Adjusted earnings for the six months ended June 30 were $1.17 per share compared to $1.08 per share for the same period a year ago. Adjusted pre-tax earnings increased $40 million in the second quarter compared to the same period last year.
Adjusted EBITDA for the merchant generation business was $50 million higher than the second quarter last year. Unhedged net revenue increased by $55 million. Youâ€™ll find details in the appendix, but let me give you an overview of what drove this increase.
The improvement in unhedged net revenue was driven by an increase in realized energy price at our generating stations of $3 per megawatt hour. Round-the-clock price at the PJM Western Hub increased by $10 per megawatt hour, but basis and shaping expanded by $7 per megawatt hour resulting in the $3 price increase at our generation stations.
Generation volume increased 2.5 million megawatt hours quarter-over-quarter. The higher generation volume was due to higher prices, reduced planned outages, and higher demand.
In addition, capacity revenues increased $24 million reflecting an average increase in capacity price of $44 per megawatt day. These increases were partially offset by increased coal costs of approximately $5 per ton and the higher coal burned due to increased generation output.
We also experienced a $40 million reduction in power hedge margin, which is the difference between the average contract price on our hedges and the current period cost of serving those contracts, including the cost of energy, capacity, ancillary services, and congestion.
Favorable contracts in the second quarter 2009 have rolled off and since market prices have increased, the margin contribution of our hedges in the second quarter of 2010 was $40 million or $7 per megawatt hour less than last year.
O&M expenses improved significantly quarter-over-quarter. $34 million was related to the timing of special maintenance for our Merchant Generation plans. We had significant planned outages in the second quarter of 2009 and very little this quarter.
As shown on slide number 29, our 2010 special maintenance expense will be higher in both the third and fourth quarters compared to 2009, but will be lower for the whole year.
Moving back to the EBITDA summary, regulated operations benefited primarily from our transmission expansion projects. We reversed $9 million of O&M expense to record a regulatory asset related to the February storm costs. We also experienced an increase in industrial and residential load, excluding the Virginian distribution business.
The primary driver of operating expenses and other is the effect of the Virginia sale. Interest expense for the quarter was higher by $21 million; about $9 million was primarily due to the fact that we stopped capitalizing interest cost on the Hatfield scrubber project. We also had an $8 million increase in interest cost due to transmission expansion and higher borrowing rates.
Depreciation increased by $13 million, primarily due to the Hatfield and Fort Martin scrubbers being placed in service in the second half of last year.
While not shown here, our effective tax rate for the quarter was approximately 38% compared to about 40% for the same period last year. Adjusted cash flow from operations was $191 million, a $143 million decrease from the second quarter last year. This was due to changes in working capital, primarily related to returns of collateral deposits in accordance with changes at PJM in the second quarter of 2009.
Capital expenditures were $246 million. Free cash flow, netting the securitization proceeds used to fund the Fort Martin scrubbers and financing for TrAIL was a positive $49 million for the quarter.
In aggregate, our liquidity, including cash on hand, totals approximately $2.3 billion. In July, AE Supply redeemed 151 million of its medium term notes with cash on hand. We have no remaining debt maturities through 2011 except for securitization and amortizations.
Now, letâ€™s turn to the outlook. This slide summarizes our most recent estimate of changes in EBITDA for 2010 compared to 2009 for each business and for consolidated depreciation and interest expense. Weâ€™re also reflecting changes in the 2010 outlook from the last call. Weâ€™ll now go through the drivers of each one of these line items.
Moving to slide number 34, for Merchant Generation, we estimate a $12 million decrease in 2010 EBITDA compared to 2009, which is a $43 million improvement compared to our estimate on the last call. Not included in these estimates is an unplanned outage at Unit 1 of our Hatfield plant which began on July 23.
We expect the outage to last about 30 days. This will result in an estimated average impact including the effect of loss margin of about $5 million to $10 million pre-tax.
Our estimates are based on among other things forward power prices at June 30, 2010. For the full year 2010, we are using a PJM Western Hub energy price of $46 per megawatt hour, which is the combination of six months actual and six months of forward prices. You may recall that on our last call, our estimates were based on forward prices of $40 per megawatt hour for 2010.
Forward prices are subject to highly variable market factors and our estimates will continue to change due to fluctuations in those prices and other factors. Since our last call, the increase in forward energy prices has contributed to a projected increase in unhedged energy margin of $90 million and a decrease in power hedge margin of $49 million.
Turning to slide number 35, we are expecting to generate 8 million more megawatt hours than in 2009. This is an increase of 1 million megawatt hours from our last call. We have generated 17 million megawatt hours year-to-date through June. Our estimated realized price for the year is $38 per megawatt hour.
Coal expense includes the cost of both contracted coal and our small open position. We are estimating an increase in coal expense of $18 million from the last call, due primarily to increased generation volume. $56 million increase in capacity reflects a $26 per megawatt day increase in capacity prices.
Operating expenses, primarily O&M and state and local taxes will increase by about $4 million. So in summary, weâ€™re expecting our unhedged EBITDA to be better by $137 million.
Adjusted EBITDA is calculated on slide number 36 by starting with the unhedged EBITDA from the prior slide and adjusting for the impact of our power hedge position. These hedges include financial hedges, our West Penn PLR contract, which expires at the end of the year and other marketing contracts.
The projected margin contribution of our hedges has decreased from our last call reflecting higher energy prices. In the appendix, we provide additional information for analyzing the business and some high level pre-tax income sensitivities.
Moving on to slide number 37, utility operations, please remember that weâ€™re including the regulated generation business of Mon Power in these results. EBITDA for utility operations is now expected to decrease by $24 million. This is $28 million worse than our estimate on the last call.
Weâ€™ve adjusted our winter storms driver to reflect the increased amount of the West Virginia regulatory asset associated with the storm. Weâ€™re reflecting the effect of moving internal resources from Pennsylvania Act 129 projects to non-capital projects. This results in an additional O&M expense of $7 million.
Weâ€™re projecting a decrease in other regulated revenues. While this reflects an increase in customer load in 2010 driven by higher industrial sales, we are expecting lower commercial usage and lower average customer rates to more than offset this benefit.
We are increasing other non-formulaic O&M by $3 million to reflect allocation of cost to this segment. Other includes among other items increases in expected third-party transmission expenses in this segment of the business.
Slide 38 shows estimated growth in rate base for utility operations. Please note that these are only estimates and our plans are always subject to change. In Pennsylvania, we have received an administrative law judge order recommending approval of our previously submitted smart meter plan.
Weâ€™re reflecting that plan in our estimated rate base amount. We expect to submit the revised plan later this year that would result in a slower smart meter-related spend. We will keep you informed on this matter.
We have also included $340 million, primarily in the outer years in transmission projects approved through the RTEP process. Weâ€™re increasing our estimate for 2010 transmission expansion EBITDA primarily based on the accelerated timing of capital expenditures in 2010. TrAIL is expected to be in service in mid 2011, PATH is expected to be in service 2015.
The rate base in our transmission expansion business is expected to grow to about $2.5 billion by 2014. For TrAIL and PATH, we earn a return in this business as capital expenditures are made. In addition to TrAIL and PATH, our estimate includes $170 million in additional PJM-approved RTEP projects that will be constructed in our transmission expansion business.
At the consolidated level, depreciation expense will increase by $44 million in 2010 due primarily to the scrubbers going into service in the second half of 2009. Fort Martin scrubbers will increase depreciation expense, but will not affect earnings because this expense is recovered through a surcharge.
Our capital forecast is reflected on slide number 42. It includes the changes to the PATH budget and in service dates. Spending in the Merchant Generation business is expected to decline now that we have completed the Hatfield scrubbers. Also included are the $510 million of PJM RTEP projects that I mentioned earlier.
Moving back to the income statement, 2010 current estimated interest expense is $47 million worse than 2009. Remember that interest expense for transmission expansion is recovered in formula rates. The Hatfield scrubbers have been placed in service and interest that was previously being capitalized will now be expensed.
Finally, while not reflected here, we expect our effective tax rate in 2010 to be about the same as our 2009 rate which was 38%. With that, Iâ€™ll turn the call over to the operator of questions.

componenttextpreview: Yes. Well, itâ€™s really primarily because of the special maintenance costs that we incurred this year relative to last year. Weâ€™ve 10 supercritical units, so on average weâ€™re doing a little more than three every year. Last year we had all three in th
componenttext:
Yes. Well, itâ€™s really primarily because of the special maintenance costs that we incurred this year relative to last year. Weâ€™ve 10 supercritical units, so on average weâ€™re doing a little more than three every year. Last year we had all three in the second quarter and this year we really had none. So there was a big difference in cost. Last year also we were doing the tie-in of our first major scrubber unit as part of a planned outage. So the difference is $5 million this year versus $41 million last year, so itâ€™s $37 million less special maintenance in the second quarter.
But I think, Brian, you should realize that this year itâ€™s kind of a normal quarter. I think in Kirkâ€™s slide it shows maybe $59 million as the total special maintenance costs for the year. Next year weâ€™re planning the same thing about three planned outages on the major units and the cost will be around the same in that whole $16 million range. So it just happened to be the timing on this quarter. Part of that reverses because last year, as Iâ€™ve said, we did everything in the second quarter, so there is very little expenses in the third and fourth quarter of last year and they are more this year.

Yes, other regulated revenues, what that reflects is while weâ€™ve had an improvement, some improvement in terms of load. Weâ€™ve had some customers coming back; itâ€™s been more on the industrial side than on the commercial and residential side. So with respect to what we were expecting on the last call, weâ€™re getting more lower margin customers and less of the higher margin customers, thatâ€™s really whatâ€™s driving that.
And then in other, what you have there is, there is I think quite a bit of transmission, third party transmission build and in some of our jurisdictions we donâ€™t have an automatic pass-through of that. So thatâ€™s some of the impact there, plus last year we sold a couple of small businesses, one of which we booked a gain on last year that weâ€™re not getting this year. So those are kind of the bigger ticket items, then there is a whole bunch of other cats and dogs in there.

componenttext: Just a follow-up on some of Danieleâ€™s questions about PATH. headline: Allegheny Energy Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-04-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, I donâ€™t see it as a threat to the PATH line at all myself. I mean PJM and their RTEP has evaluated a whole series of possible lines and one was a proposal that Dominion had some time ago and which they rated those and PATH, clearly, came out number
componenttext:
Yes, I donâ€™t see it as a threat to the PATH line at all myself. I mean PJM and their RTEP has evaluated a whole series of possible lines and one was a proposal that Dominion had some time ago and which they rated those and PATH, clearly, came out number one meeting all the needs going forward for an extended period. Dominion has made now some changes to what they have re-proposed.
So the PJM RTEP is looking at it, but it is really focused on one line only. This is Mt. Storm to Doubs line, which is a rebuild of an existing line. So itâ€™s not very easy and simple to do. We have to take out the line at certain periods, put it back. It solves one issue.
I think PATH is certainly the more robust long-term solution creating an entirely additional high voltage corridor that will help power flow throughout the whole system providing capacity for the whole system. So weâ€™re going forward full speed ahead with PATH, and PJM, weâ€™ll look at that one. It might be a nice supplemental one, but to me itâ€™s really not a threat and the PJM hasnâ€™t even decided what to do with that particular line even though Dominion makes some comments perhaps suggesting something otherwise.

Good afternoon, everyone, and thanks for joining us. If you have to leave the call before it's over, you can listen to the taped replay. You can listen to the replay by telephone on our website or by podcast, and we'll make it available through August 11. 
Some of our statements will be forward-looking. These statements involve risks and uncertainties and are based on currently available information. Actual results may differ significantly from the results and the outlook we discuss today. Please refer to our earnings news release and our SEC filings regarding factors that may cause actual results to differ from the forward-looking statements made on this call. 
Our presentation includes some non-GAAP financial measures. On our website, you'll find the reconciliations required under the SEC's Regulation G. After our prepared remarks, we will take your questions, and we do ask that you try to limit your questions to two each, so we have time to get to as many of you as possible. And now, let me introduce Paul Evanson, Chairman, President and Chief Executive Officer of Allegheny Energy.

headline: Allegheny Energy Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-04-2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Max, and good afternoon, everyone, and thanks for joining us. Today, we reported adjusted earnings of $0.57 per share for the second quarter, up substantially from $0.41 a year ago. These results exclude costs related to our proposed merger with F
componenttext:
Thanks, Max, and good afternoon, everyone, and thanks for joining us. Today, we reported adjusted earnings of $0.57 per share for the second quarter, up substantially from $0.41 a year ago. These results exclude costs related to our proposed merger with FirstEnergy, unrealized losses on hedges and a $45 million gain on the sale of our Virginia territory. 
A number of factors affected our results, but a major factor was lower operations and maintenance expense. These lower costs were primarily due to timing of special maintenance expenses at the merchant power plants. Such costs were down $34 million in the quarter over the prior period. We had less than one week of planned outages in this quarter compared to 21 weeks in the same period last year, when we were doing maintenance at three supercritical plants. 
Results in the second quarter also benefited from a 41% increase in Merchant Generation output, reflecting the fewer planned outages, higher power prices and stronger demand. The capacity factor of the supercriticals was back to a more normal 76% in the quarter. The higher revenues were partially offset by the roll off of favorable power hedges. 
In our Regulated business, overall sales were up 3.5% in the second quarter this year. Industrial sales increased 9%, continuing the trend that we saw in the first quarter. These figures exclude sales in Virginia. We completed the sale of our Virginia Distribution operations on June 1 of this year. 
In addition, we reversed $9 million [$8.9 million] of West Virginia storm costs booked in the first quarter because of a favorable commission ruling. Finally, earnings from our transmission projects benefited results in the quarter. 
Now looking at key areas of focus for the year, we've made good progress on our top priority, completing the merger with FirstEnergy. On July 16, the Securities and Exchange Commission declared our registration statement effective, and we mailed our proxy material. A special meeting to approve the merger is set for September 14. FirstEnergy will also hold it's shareholder meeting that same day. 
In addition, we filed all required applications for regulatory approval, both federal and state. Procedural schedules are now in place in all jurisdictions. As you would expect with the merger of this size and scope, a number of parties have intervened in the proceedings. Based on the schedule, we think it's reasonable to expect decisions in Virginia as early as September from the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission in the fourth quarter and in Pennsylvania, Maryland and West Virginia in the first quarter of next year. 
Turning now to our other priority. We remain on track for a smooth transition to market-based rates in Pennsylvania, where rate caps expire at the end of this year. Our Regulated business has contracted about 70% of the power needed to serve residential and small and medium commercial and industrial customers for the full year 2011. Based on the contracts in place and assuming future prices are similar to the most recent auction, average monthly residential electric bills would only increase 4%, while small commercial and industrial bills would actually decrease by 2%. The next auction will be held in October, and is heavily weighted toward commercial and industrial load. 
Moving now to our transmission projects. The 500-kV Trans-Allegheny Interstate Line or TrAIL remains on schedule for in service in June 2011. The right-of-way acquisition and substation construction are nearly complete. 83% of the towers have been constructed, and 48% of the wire has been installed. 
Regarding our second transmission project, the 765-kV, Potomac-Appalachian Transmission Highline or PATH. In June PJM reaffirmed the need for the project and set the new in-service state for June 1, 2015. This confirmation is a major step forward for the project. 
We've already begun to reengage the state regulatory approval process. We've made additional regulatory filings in Maryland, and we'll refile in Virginia, where we withdrew our application last year. In West Virginia, we anticipate a decision in May 2011. 
We've also revisited the budget for the project, since it's been three year since we first put it together. With increases in the cost of materials and services, as well as new government agency requirements, we now estimate Allegheny share of the revised PATH budget as $1.4 billion. That's up $200 million from the original estimate. 
Another accomplishment during the second quarter was the regulatory approval of our West Virginia base rate case. The first phase, a $40 million increase, went into effect on June 29, and the second phase, a $20 million increase will go into effect in January. 
In other developments. Allegheny Energy Supply recently won power supply contracts in Maryland and Pennsylvania and has entered into some commercial and industrial marketing contracts. As a result, we are now 89% hedged for the remainder of 2010, 59% in 2011, 23% in 2012 and 5% in 2013, all of which is consistent with the targets we've communicated in the past. That is, by the end of the given year, we will only have had 80% to 90% of the next year's output, 30% to 50% of year two and 0% to 30% of year three. 
The capacity auction for 2013, '14 was held in mid May. The clearing price was $28 per megawatt-day in that region, an increase over the previous auction but still well below results for prior years and well below what's needed to stimulate new investment. 
On the environmental front, Allegheny is reviewing the impact of the clean air transport rule at the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency proposed in early July. The new rule substantially replaces the Clean Air Interstate Rule that the federal court overturned. The rule imposes state-by-state limits for sulfur dioxide and NOx emissions and restricts interstate trading, thereby limiting our ability to trade emission allowances to comply. 
There's also a different approach in Washington to propose climate change legislation. When it became clear, an economy-wide carbon bill did not have sufficient support in the Senate, the utilities-only version began to be discussed. That is, the bill would regulate greenhouse gases for the utility industry only. It seems unlikely that even this limited version will be enacted this year. 
And finally, I'm happy to report that Allegheny won second place in the American Society for Quality's 2010 international team competition. More than 400 applicants worldwide competed on how they have used the quality process to improve operations. The Allegheny team reported on a project that improved order fulfillment within supply chain. To finished second is really quite an accomplishment. Improving quality of service and reducing costs, that's what I call high performance. 
So to summarize, while we continue to face a tough economy, we're making solid progress on meeting our goals and objectives for the year. While working hard to complete our merger with FirstEnergy, we remained focused on our core business, especially controlling costs and looking for value-added opportunities. Now let me turn the call over to Kirk.

headline: Allegheny Energy Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-04-2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Paul, and good afternoon, everyone. As Paul has already discussed, adjusted earnings for the second quarter were $0.57 per share as compared to $0.41 per share for the second quarter of last year. Adjusted earnings for the quarter exclude net u
componenttext:
Thank you, Paul, and good afternoon, everyone. As Paul has already discussed, adjusted earnings for the second quarter were $0.57 per share as compared to $0.41 per share for the second quarter of last year. Adjusted earnings for the quarter exclude net unrealized losses associated with hedging activities, expenses associated with the proposed merger with FirstEnergy and a $45 million gain from the sale of the Virginia Distribution business. 
Adjusted earnings for the six months ended June 30 were $1.17 per share compared to $1.08 per share for the same period a year ago. Adjusted pretax earnings increased $40 million in the second quarter compared to the same period last year. Adjusted EBITDA for the Merchant Generation business was $50 million higher than the second quarter last year. Unhedged net revenue increased by $55 million. You'll find details in the Appendix, but let me give you an overview of what drove this increase. 
The improvement in unhedged net revenue was driven by an increase in realized energy price at our generating stations, up $3 per megawatt-hour. The round-the-clock price at the PJM Western Hub increased by $10 per megawatt-hour, but basis and shaping expanded by $7 per megawatt-hour,  resulting in the $3 price increase at our generation stations. 
Generation volume increased 2.5 million megawatt-hours quarter-over-quarter. The higher generation volume was due to higher prices, reduced planned outages and higher demand. In addition, capacity revenues increased $24 million, reflecting an average increase in capacity price of $44 per megawatt-day. These increases were partially offset by increased coal costs of approximately $5 per ton and the higher coal burn due to increased generation output. 
We also experienced a $40 million reduction in power hedge margin, which is the difference between the average contract price on our hedges and the current period cost of serving those contracts, including the cost of energy, capacity, ancillary services and congestion. Favorable contracts in the second quarter 2009 have rolled off, and since market prices have increased, the margin contribution of our hedges in the second quarter of 2010 was $40 million or $7 per megawatt-hour less than last year. 
O&M expenses improved significantly quarter-over-quarter. $34 million was related to the timing of special maintenance for our Merchant Generation plants. We had significant plant outages in the second quarter of 2009 and very little this quarter. As shown on Slide 29, our 2010 special maintenance expense will be higher in both the third and fourth quarters compared to 2009, but will be lower for the whole year. 
Moving back to the EBITDA summary. Regulated Operations benefited primarily from our transmission expansion projects. We reversed $9 million of O&M expense to record a regulatory asset related to the February storm cost. We also experienced an increase in industrial and residential load, excluding the Virginia Distribution business. The primary driver of operating expenses and other is the effect of the Virginia sale. 
Interest expense for the quarter was higher by $21 million. About $9 million was primarily due to the fact that we stopped capitalizing interest cost on the Hatfield scrubber project. We also had an $8 million increase in interest cost due to transmission expansion and higher borrowing rates.  Depreciation increased by $13 million primarily due to the Hatfield and Fort Martin scrubbers being placed in service in the second half of last year. While not shown here, our effective tax rate for the quarter was approximately 38% compared to about 40% for the same period last year. 
Adjusted cash flow from operations was $191 million, a $43 million decrease from the second quarter last year. This was due to changes in working capital, primarily related to returns of collateral deposits in accordance with changes at PJM in the second quarter of 2009. Capital expenditures were $246 million. Free cash flow, netting the securitization proceeds used to fund the Fort Martin scrubbers and financing for TrAIL was a positive $49 million for the quarter. 
In aggregate, our liquidity, including cash on hand, totals approximately $2.3 billion. In July, AE Supply redeemed $151 million of its medium-term notes with cash on hand. We have no remaining debt maturities through 2011 except for securitization amortizations. 
Now let's turn to the outlook. This slide summarizes our most recent estimate of changes in EBITDA for 2010 compared to 2009 for each business and for consolidated depreciation and interest expense. We're also reflecting changes in the 2010 outlook from the last call. We'll now go through the drivers of each one of these line items. 
Moving to Slide 34 for Merchant Generation. We estimate a $12 million decrease in 2010 EBITDA compared to 2009, which is a $43 million improvement compared to our estimate on the last call. Not included in these estimates is an unplanned outage at Unit 1 of our Hatfield plant, which began on July  23. We expect the outage to last about 30 days. This will result in an estimated adverse impact, including the effect of loss margin of about $5 million to $10 million pretax. 
Our estimates are based on, among other things, forward power prices at June 30, 2010. For the full year 2010, we are using a PJM Western Hub energy price of $46 per megawatt-hour, which is the combination of six months actual and six months of forward prices. 
You may recall that on our last call, our estimates were based on forward prices of $40 per megawatt-hour for 2010. Forward prices are subject to highly variable market factors, and our estimates will continue to change due to fluctuations in those prices and other factors. Since our last call, the increase in forward energy prices has contributed to a projected increase in unhedged energy margin of $90 million and a decrease in power hedge margin of $49 million. 
Turning to Slide 35. We are expecting to generate 8 million more megawatt-hours than in 2009. This is an increase of 1 million megawatt-hours from our last call. We have generated 17 million-megawatt hours year-to-date through June. Our estimated realized price for the year is $38 per megawatt-hour. 
Call expense includes cost of both contracted coal in our small open position. We're estimating an increase in coal expense of $18 million from the last call due primarily to increased generation volume. The $56 million increase in capacity reflects a $26 per megawatt-day increase in capacity prices. Operating expenses, primarily O&M and state and local taxes will increase by about $4 million. 
So in summary, we're expecting our unhedged EBITDA to be better by $137 million. Adjusted EBITDA is calculated on Slide 36 by starting with the unhedged EBITDA from the prior slide and adjusting for the impact of our power hedge position. These hedges include financial hedges, our West Penn POLR contract, which expires at the end of the year and other marketing contracts. The projected margin contribution of our hedges has decreased from our last call, reflecting higher energy prices. In the Appendix, we provide additional information for analyzing the business and some high-level pretax income sensitivities. 
Moving on to Slide 37, utility operations. Please remember that we are including the Regulated Generation business of Mon Power in these results. EBITDA for utility operations is now expected to decrease by $24 million. This is $28 million worse than our estimate on the last call. We've adjusted our winter storm's driver to reflect the increased amount of the West Virginia regulatory asset associated with the storm. We're reflecting the effect of moving internal resources from Pennsylvania Act 129 projects to non-capital projects. This results in an additional O&M expense of $7 million. 
We're projecting a decrease in other regulated revenues. While this reflects an increase in customer load in 2010 driven by higher industrial sales, we are expecting lower commercial usage and lower average customer rates to more than offset this benefit. We are increasing other non-formulated O&M $3 million to reflect allocation of cost to this segment. Other includes, among other items, increases in expected third-party transmission expenses in this segment of the business. 
Slide 38 shows estimated growth in rate base for utility operations. Please note that these are only estimates, and our plans are always subject to change. In Pennsylvania, we have received an administrative law judge order recommending approval of our previously submitted Smart Meter plan. We're reflecting that plan in our estimated rate base amount. We expect to submit a revised plan better this year that would result in a slower Smart-Meter-related spend. We will keep you informed on this matter. We have also included $340 million, primarily in the outer years in transmission projects approved through the RTEP process. 
We're increasing our estimate for 2010 Transmission Expansion EBITDA, primarily based on the accelerated timing of capital expenditures in 2010. TrAIL is expected to be in service in mid 2011. PATH is expected to be in service, 2015. 
The rate base in our Transition Expansion business is expected to grow to about $2.5 billion by 2014. For TrAIL and PATH, we earn a return in this business as capital expenditures are made. In addition to TrAIL and PATH, our estimate includes $170 million and additional PJM-approved RTEP projects that will be constructed in our Transmission Expansion business. 
At the consolidated level, depreciation expense will increase by $44 million in 2010 due primarily to the scrubbers going in service in the second half of 2009. Fort Martin scrubbers will increase depreciation expense but will not affect earnings, because these expenses recover through a surcharge. 
Our capital forecast is reflected on Slide 42. It includes the changes to PATH budget and in-service dates. Spending in the Merchant Generation business is expected to decline now that we have completed the Hatfield scrubbers. Also included are the $510 million of PJM RTEP projects that I mentioned earlier. 
Moving back to the income statement. 2010 current estimated interest expense is $47 million worse than 2009. Remember that interest expense for Transmission Expansion has recovered in formula rates. The Hatfield scrubbers have been placed in service, and interest that was been capitalized will now be expensed. 
Finally, while not reflected here, we expect our effective tax rate in 2010 to be about the same as our 2009 rate, which was 38%. With that, I'll turn the call over to the operator for questions.

headline: Allegheny Energy Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-04-2010
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our first question will come from Brian Chin from Citigroup.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our first question will come from Brian Chin from Citigroup.

headline: Allegheny Energy Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-04-2010
componenttextpreview: I want to make sure I confirm a comment, I think, you made on O&M expenses. Is it that the O&M expenses this quarter were abnormally below and that you simply just shifted some of those expenses to the third and fourth quarter? Did I hear that right?
componenttext: I want to make sure I confirm a comment, I think, you made on O&M expenses. Is it that the O&M expenses this quarter were abnormally below and that you simply just shifted some of those expenses to the third and fourth quarter? Did I hear that right?

headline: Allegheny Energy Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-04-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes. Well, it's really primarily because of the special maintenance costs that we incurred this year relative to last year. We have 10 supercritical units, we sell on average. We're doing a little more than three every year. And last year, we had all thre
componenttext: Yes. Well, it's really primarily because of the special maintenance costs that we incurred this year relative to last year. We have 10 supercritical units, we sell on average. We're doing a little more than three every year. And last year, we had all three in the second quarter, and this year, we really had none. So there was a big difference in cost. And last year also, we were doing the tie-ins of our first major scrubber unit as part of a planned outage. So the difference is $5 million this year versus $41 million last year. So it's $37 million less special maintenance in the second quarter. But, I think, Brian, you should realize that this year is kind of a normal quarter. So we -- I think in Kirk's slide, it shows maybe $59 million as the total special maintenance costs for the year. And next year, we're planning the same thing, about three planned outages on the major units, and the cost will be around the same in that old $60 million range, though it just happened to be the timing on this quarter. And part of that reverse is because last year, as I said, we did everything in the second quarter, so there's very little expenses in the third and fourth quarter of last year, and there are more this year.

headline: Allegheny Energy Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-04-2010
componenttextpreview: And then secondly, I noticed that your coal-hedged volumes declined, looking out into '11 and '12. Can you just provide a little bit more color there, as particular point of view that you're espousing? Or is there some other issue?
componenttext: And then secondly, I noticed that your coal-hedged volumes declined, looking out into '11 and '12. Can you just provide a little bit more color there, as particular point of view that you're espousing? Or is there some other issue?

componenttext: No, that's just moving some of the volumes among the years a little bit, and then, the percentages go down because we're projecting higher burn rates. So we're burning more coal.

componenttext: As you mentioned, now that all the filings are in and you're starting to see intervenor, some of these coming in, anything so far in there in that process that has surprised you when you do this?

componenttext: No, there's nothing kind of out of the blue so far that we've seen. I mean the intervenors are probably what you consider the usual suspects, the commission staffs, the public counsel, the industrial, the unions. There are a few special ones in there, but I don't think that to date, it's been going pretty well. So there are no special items that are up. We still have concern of course in Pennsylvania. We had a public hearing yesterday, the first and only one here in Greensburg, where jobs is a concern. So apart from that, which is kind of what you would expect in this type of merger, there hasn't been anything quite out of the ordinary yet.

headline: Allegheny Energy Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-04-2010

componenttext: And second question, looking at your total generation volume numbers updated versus previously, has it gone up some, particularly the 2012 number. Again, is that a function of better-forward curves, causing more dispatch, or anything operationally on your end?

componenttext: Our next question comes from Paul Patterson from Glenrock Associates.

headline: Allegheny Energy Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-04-2010
componenttextpreview: Just to sort of follow-up on Slide 51. It looks to me that you have increased substantially the amount that hedged for the power hedges, yet the margin's down for the power hedge margins and not much up for 2012. I'm talking about 2011, 2012. What are the
componenttext: Just to sort of follow-up on Slide 51. It looks to me that you have increased substantially the amount that hedged for the power hedges, yet the margin's down for the power hedge margins and not much up for 2012. I'm talking about 2011, 2012. What are the dynamics that are happening there?

headline: Allegheny Energy Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-04-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, these reflect the market at the point in time. So to the extent we had hedges on, we're remarking those hedges. So if prices have come up, you'll see the margin on those hedges go down. And then, of course, to the extent we layer in more hedges that
componenttext: Well, these reflect the market at the point in time. So to the extent we had hedges on, we're remarking those hedges. So if prices have come up, you'll see the margin on those hedges go down. And then, of course, to the extent we layer in more hedges that will be a function of what price we layer those hedges in. So you're seeing a combination of those two things affecting the numbers.

componenttext: Now, when we look at the coal contract, I think Brian sort of brought this up. It does look like the contract price has risen in 2012 and 2011, although there was only a sort of a slight decrease in the amount hedged I guess because of some movement that you indicate some from one year to the other. componenttext: Well, I'm not completely sure on that. We can follow up on it. But to the extent we can, we'll move the lower contracted -- lower cost coal up. That could explain it, but I would have to actually to check on that to make sure.

componenttext: Yes. Primarily, last year in the second quarter, PJM changed the way they held collateral, and they've started releasing instead of monthly, I think it was weekly. Some of the collateral, we have to post with PJM. So we had a one-time benefit in the second quarter last year, that we're not getting this year.

componenttext: And then, just looking at Slide 37, couple of small items, but they kind of add up. The other regulated revenues went down to $8 million, and then other went down $13 million versus last call. What are those two line items?

headline: Allegheny Energy Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-04-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes. Other regulated revenues, what that reflects is, while we've had an improvement, some improvement in terms of load, we've had some customers coming back. It's been more on the industrial side than on the commercial and residential side. So with respe
componenttext: Yes. Other regulated revenues, what that reflects is, while we've had an improvement, some improvement in terms of load, we've had some customers coming back. It's been more on the industrial side than on the commercial and residential side. So with respect to what we were expecting on the last call, we're getting more lower margin customers and less of the higher-margin customers. That's really what's driving that. And then in other, what you have there is there's been quite a bit of third-party transmission build, and in some of our jurisdictions, we don't have an automatic pass-through of that. So that's some of the impact there. Plus last year, we sold a couple of small businesses, one of which, we booked again on last, last year that we're not getting this year. So those are the kind of the bigger-ticket items, then there's a whole bunch of other cats and dogs in there.

headline: Allegheny Energy Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-04-2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Edward Heyn from Catapult.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Edward Heyn from Catapult.

headline: Allegheny Energy Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-04-2010
componenttextpreview: Paul, I think you touched on this a little bit in your prepared remarks about the CAIR Transport Rule [Clean Air Interstate Rule]. I was wondering if you could talk a little bit more given the fact that your fleet kind of falls across state lines, is ther
componenttext: Paul, I think you touched on this a little bit in your prepared remarks about the CAIR Transport Rule [Clean Air Interstate Rule]. I was wondering if you could talk a little bit more given the fact that your fleet kind of falls across state lines, is there anything issue related to the trading of credits? Are you imbalanced, I guess, having more credits or long or short in Pennsylvania or West Virginia, or I think you also have a small Maryland plant, which is a Paul Smith. Does the distribution of those create any issues for you guys that we should be thinking about?

headline: Allegheny Energy Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-04-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, we are still going through -- trying to design the best we can the impact of it. But I think the narrowing of the ability to move those credits along state lines likely could have an impact to us. It's hard to say how large it would be. Well, maybe
componenttext: Well, we are still going through -- trying to design the best we can the impact of it. But I think the narrowing of the ability to move those credits along state lines likely could have an impact to us. It's hard to say how large it would be. Well, maybe a little long in one jurisdiction, a little short in the other. I think there would be some if it got finalized the way it is. We really haven't made a final determination on that.

headline: Allegheny Energy Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-04-2010
componenttextpreview: And then, just quickly on if we look at the NYMEX price of coal, it seems like that price has been escalating extremely rapidly. Whereas as of late, it hasn't really been commensurately followed with power prices. When you guys look at kind of the over-th
componenttext: And then, just quickly on if we look at the NYMEX price of coal, it seems like that price has been escalating extremely rapidly. Whereas as of late, it hasn't really been commensurately followed with power prices. When you guys look at kind of the over-the-counter markets, I know you see different pricing when you're actually contracting for physical prices. Is there a disconnect that you guys are seeing or are those really kind of good prices?

headline: Allegheny Energy Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-04-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, I think there's a little. If you're looking at the NYMEX, there's a little discontinuity because of course, that's just Central App coal and we're burning almost entirely Northern App coal, and that coal isn't quite suited for our boiler. And some o
componenttext: Well, I think there's a little. If you're looking at the NYMEX, there's a little discontinuity because of course, that's just Central App coal and we're burning almost entirely Northern App coal, and that coal isn't quite suited for our boiler. And some of it is more subject to export. So I think you're seeing more on that than you have -- more price movement than on the Northern App. We are seeing some but it hasn't been very dramatic at all.

headline: Allegheny Energy Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-04-2010

componenttext: Yes, it tends to be somewhat volatile. And what we saw in the quarter, what happened is, you had some very hot weather in the East and at the same time, there were some things happening with the transmission system that added to congestion. So you saw quite a bit of congestion in the second quarter, we think, related to those two items. It's really difficult to tell exactly what's driving it. So that's what happened.

componenttext: Well, the planned outages were going to have a reversal of some of the cost because in '09, all of those major outages are in the second quarter. So now we have some in the third and fourth. I think, Kirk had a slide that show we would be $10 million worse in the third quarter and about $16 million worse in the fourth quarter. Although for the full year, we'd be better. But about $26 million will turn around in the last half of the year. But then in a total basis, as you go forward from $10 million to $11 million, you'll have it exactly right because the supercritical outage weeks will be almost the same, 18 and 19. And the cost will be right around $60 million in both years. So we have that little discontinuity by quarter.

componenttext: No, that's just more of a recurring item. We have the supercritical units and each unit about every three plus or minus years, needs a kind of full outage to make a lot of changes and modifications to them. So it's a recurring item. So we expect, I mean with 10 units, we'd have like three basically every year. And that's what we're having this year and that's what we'll have next year.

componenttext: Well, for the second quarter, Daniele, we did get some warm weather. And that 47% translates to about a 79% warmer than normal. And then July has been also very warm, but I don't have the numbers on July yet.

componenttext: Well, I was saying for the full year, we'd have three outages in '10 and three outages in '11. So the total for the year would be the same. We haven't given out the data by quarter. In '11, at least. That 70% that I mentioned in second quarter is about what we've done in four of the last five years have been right around the low 70, mid-70 range. So it's very much typical.

headline: Allegheny Energy Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-04-2010
componenttextpreview: And then I guess on a broader basis, Paul, could you give us your view on how the supercriticals will fare under a CAIR and then a MACT or more green standard?
componenttext: And then I guess on a broader basis, Paul, could you give us your view on how the supercriticals will fare under a CAIR and then a MACT or more green standard?

headline: Allegheny Energy Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-04-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, I guess more broadly, I think the supercriticals will do okay on that. At least on the early years. This whole maze of EPA regulations right, I think some starting as early as 2012, some going out to 2015. There's a whole maze of them, which if made
componenttext: Well, I guess more broadly, I think the supercriticals will do okay on that. At least on the early years. This whole maze of EPA regulations right, I think some starting as early as 2012, some going out to 2015. There's a whole maze of them, which if made effective, would likely shut down most of the subcritical fleet. I think the supercriticals would probably continue to operate, and they would have to continue to operate to meet reliability but they may incur some additional costs to do so. Of course on the other hand, we're going to be seeing much higher energy and capacity prices if all these rules went into effect and a lot of the subcriticals shut down.

headline: Allegheny Energy Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-04-2010

headline: Allegheny Energy Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-04-2010

componenttext: Well, the contract does roll off at the end of this year, as you know. And we do have a retail team that were just really starting up. And so we will have what we like to think of as a three-legged stool in terms of how we do our hedging going forward. So we'll have financial hedges, we will have POLR contracts and then, we'll have a Retail business. The Retail business is in its infancy, but it's moving along.

headline: Allegheny Energy Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-04-2010
componenttextpreview: And relative to 11, I mean we are already 59% hedged of our total coal-fired output and we have a target of 80%, 90%. So we're basically tracking online to where we want to be by the end of the year. So I don't think we're going to have any shocking chang
componenttext: And relative to 11, I mean we are already 59% hedged of our total coal-fired output and we have a target of 80%, 90%. So we're basically tracking online to where we want to be by the end of the year. So I don't think we're going to have any shocking change taking place in the balance of the year on replacing that.

componenttext: And I know one of the lines has been recently, the Roseland line, delayed because of federal citing. But I can tell you we've been very focused and diligent on that right from the beginning, back when the project first came up and we've been extremely sensitive to it. And it's very important in terms of citing. And we have it down to, like, there's only 2.5 miles within federal boundaries within 276 miles of the entire project. And we started that process back two years ago. So we think our federal review is on track and shouldn't cause any delay in meeting that June 1, 2015, date.

headline: Allegheny Energy Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-04-2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question is a follow up from Edward Heyn from Catapult.
componenttext: Our next question is a follow up from Edward Heyn from Catapult.

headline: Allegheny Energy Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-04-2010
componenttextpreview: Just to follow-up on some of Daniele's questions about PATH. Another thing that we had seen I guess about a month ago was that Dominion had, I guess, like, a competing line but a line that went to address some of the same issues that PATH did and it showe
componenttext: Just to follow-up on some of Daniele's questions about PATH. Another thing that we had seen I guess about a month ago was that Dominion had, I guess, like, a competing line but a line that went to address some of the same issues that PATH did and it showed up on an RTEP presentation. I was wondering if you could give us some commentary on do you see that as a threat to the PATH line? And if so, when would kind of decisions be made on that?

headline: Allegheny Energy Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-04-2010
componenttextpreview: I don't see it as a threat to the PATH line at all myself. I mean PJM and RTEP has evaluated a whole series of possible lines, and one was a proposal that Dominion had some time ago in which they rated those, and PATH clearly came out number one, meeting
componenttext: I don't see it as a threat to the PATH line at all myself. I mean PJM and RTEP has evaluated a whole series of possible lines, and one was a proposal that Dominion had some time ago in which they rated those, and PATH clearly came out number one, meeting all the needs going forward for an extended period. Dominion has made now some changes to what they have reproposed, so the PJM RTEP is looking at it but it's really focused on one line only. This is the Mt. Storm to Doubs line, which is a rebuild of an existing line. So it's not very easy and simple to do. You have to take out the line in certain periods, put it back. And it's solves one issue. I think PATH is certainly the more robust long-term solution creating an entirely additional high-voltage corridor that will help power flow throughout the whole system, providing capacity for the whole system. So we're going forward full speed ahead with PATH and PJM will look at that one. It might be a nice supplemental one. But to me, it's really not a threat and the PJM hasn't even decided what to do with that particular line even though Dominion make some comments, perhaps suggesting something otherwise.
