Now, let me introduce Paul Evanson, Chairman, President and Chief Executive Officer of Allegheny Energy.

headline: Allegheny Energy Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks Max. Good afternoon, everyone, thanks for being with us today. I am pleased to report that we had strong financial results for the third quarter. Adjusted earnings were $0.73 per share up substantially from $0.59 in the third quarter a year ago. Th
componenttext:
Thanks Max. Good afternoon, everyone, thanks for being with us today. I am pleased to report that we had strong financial results for the third quarter. Adjusted earnings were $0.73 per share up substantially from $0.59 in the third quarter a year ago. These figures exclude costs related to our proposed merger with FirstEnergy, unrealized gains on hedges and the cost of debt tend to offers.
Our Merchant Generation business earned a solid profit, but most of our earnings growth came from regulated operations. Results from regulated operations benefited from increased earnings at our transmission expansion projects, a rate increase in West Virginia and higher retail sales.
Total retail electric sales increased by 11% compared to the same period last year and industrial sales were up 8% continuing the trend weâ€™ve seen this year. Increased sales were also driven by the hot summer weather, cooling degree-days were up nearly 50% compared to the prior year and also were well above normal.
Increased demand helped our generation business as well. Merchant plan output was up almost 50% for the quarter most of which came from our supercritical coal units.
As you may recall, in the third quarter of last year our supercritical capacity factor was under 50% due largely to weak demand and competition from gas-fired generation.
In the quarter just ended, the higher generation volume reflects both stronger demand and higher power prices. Realized energy prices in TJM increased to $44 per megawatt hour, up over 30% compared to the same period a year ago.
However, since most of our output was hedged at or near market levels, those hedges didnâ€™t help earnings as they did last year when they were above market prices and benefited earnings by $63 million pre-tax.
So overall, our third quarter results were strong for both segments of the business and indicate continued economic recovery in our service territory.
Letâ€™s now turn to our key areas of focus for the year. We continued to make good progress with our top priority merger with FirstEnergy.
On September 14, we achieved a major milestone. The shareholders of both companies overwhelmingly approved the merger. We were extremely pleased with the significant show of support from our shareholders. 99% of the votes cast were in favor of the merger.
As for the regulatory review process, we received merger approval from the Virginia State Corporation Commission on September 9. Although, hearings were held in mid-October in Pennsylvania and weâ€™ve already reached the settlement with many of the parties including the Office of Consumer Advocate and the trial staff of the Public Utility Commission. Hearings begin West Virginia and Maryland within the next two weeks.
On the Federal level, we are awaiting the completion of reviews by the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission and the Department of Justice. We donâ€™t expect either of these reviews to delay the closing which remains on schedule for the first half of 2011.
Now as per our transmission projects, the 500-kV Trans-Allegheny Interstate Line or TrAIL as we call it, is nearing completion. The right of way acquisition and substation construction are essentially finished and construction of the line itself is headed down the home stretch.
97% of the towers are complete and 76% of the wire is installed. The line remains scheduled for in service in June 2011 five years after we were directed to build it by PJM and frankly much faster than almost anyone thought possible.
Our second transmission project, the 765-kV Potomac-Appalachian Transmission Highline or PATH, is also moving forward following PJMâ€™s affirmation that the line is needed by June 1, 2015.
We had a favorable development in Virginia last week when the State Corporation Commission denied a staff motion that said the case should be held in abeyance. The Commission instead set a procedural schedule that includes an evidentiary hearing in April of next year.
We expect the Virginia Commission to make a decision on PATH no later than September 2011. West Virginia, has also scheduled hearings in March of next year and is expected to make a decision by late July. Procedural schedules should be set in Maryland in the near future. We expect the Maryland Commission to make a decision no later than next September.
Also we opened our new transmission headquarters building near Fairmont, West Virginia last week. The new $60 million environmentally friendly facility will bring 150 jobs to West Virginia when fully staffed, and is a major economic development boost to the area.
The facility will serve as the nerve center for our multi-state transmission function that includes a state-of-the-art transmission operation center that will manage the grid 24-hours a day, seven-days a week. Itâ€™s an appropriate facility to have Allegheny growing transmission business which is just so critical in the PJM regions.
On the legal front, the federal trial has concluded in the loss of over alleged New Source Review violations of the Clean Air Act at our three Pennsylvania power plants. Alleghenyâ€™s position remains that all planned outage work at the plants did not trigger New Source Review or related state law. The Judgesâ€™ decision is not expected until sometime next year.
Since our last call, Allegheny Energy Supply has won additional power supply contracts and has entered into some direct contracts with retail customers. As a result, our Merchant Generation business is now 74% hedged in 2011, 29% in 2012, and 7% in 2013.
This is consistent with the targets weâ€™ve communicated in the past, and that is, by the end of a given year we want to have hedged 80% to 90% of the next yearâ€™s output, 30% to 50% of the year two, and 0% to 30% of year three.
In preparation for the exploration of rate caps at the end of this year, West Penn Power a Pennsylvania utility held its final option to procure power for 2011. The Maryland supply contract is in place for the full year to serve the needs of 80% of our residential customers, 90% of our small and mid-sized non residential customers, and all of our largest commercial and industrial customers through selected fixed price option.
The remainder of West Pennâ€™s needs through 2011 will be procured through daily spot purchases. Based on the prices power under contract, average monthly residential electric bills will increase only $3 per month or about 3% next year. Electric bills for small to mid-sized non residential customers will actually decrease between 3% and 4%.
Now, Iâ€™m also happy to report that Allegheny Power continues to rank in the top-quartile of utilities nationwide for overall customer satisfaction among large commercial and industrial customers according to the recently published 2010 TQS survey.
In the same survey, Allegheny also continued to rank number one among utilities into North East region for the sixth consecutive year.
So, in summary, Allegheny Energy had a strong third quarter and weâ€™re making solid progress on meeting our goals and objectives for the year. As we look out over the next few months, we remained very focused on running our core business well and completing the merger with FirstEnergy.
Now, let me turn the call over to Kirk.

headline: Allegheny Energy Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Paul. Good afternoon, everyone. As Paul has already discussed, adjusted earnings for the third quarter was $0.73 per share as compared to $0.59 per share for the third quarter of last year.Adjusted earnings for the quarter exclude net unreali
componenttext:
Thank you, Paul. Good afternoon, everyone. As Paul has already discussed, adjusted earnings for the third quarter was $0.73 per share as compared to $0.59 per share for the third quarter of last year.
Adjusted earnings for the quarter exclude net unrealized gains associated with hedging activities, expenses associated with the proposed merger with FirstEnergy, and tender offer costs.
Adjusted earnings for the nine months ended September 30 were $1.91 per share compared to $1.67 per share for the same period a year ago. Adjusted pre-tax earnings increased by $29 million in the third quarter compared to the same period last year.
Adjusted EBITDA for the merchant generation was $3 million higher than the third quarter last year. Unhedged net revenue increased by $81 million. Youâ€™ll find details in the appendix, but let me give you an overview of what drove this increase. The improvement in unhedged net revenue was driven by an increase in both price and volume.
Round the clock price at the PJM Western Hub increased by $18 per megawatt hour, but basis and shaping expanded by $7 per megawatt hour resulting in an $11 price increase at our generation stations.
Generation volume increased 3 million megawatt hours quarter-over-quarter. A higher generation volume was due primarily to higher realized prices and higher demand.
Capacity revenues decreased $12 million. This reflects a decrease in the PJM base auction price from the $191 to $174 per megawatt day. Balancing auction activity certainly affects the plant availability. Coal expense increased by $59 million, primarily due to higher coal burn related to increase generation output.
We also experienced $66 million reduction in power hedge margins, which is the difference between the average contract price on our hedges and the current period cost of serving those contracts, including the cost of energy, capacity, ancillary services, and congestion.
This quarter the contract prices of our hedges were roughly equal to market prices and had little impact on the quarter.
In the third quarter of 2009, contract prices of our hedges exceeded the cost to serve these hedge obligations by $9 per megawatt hour resulting in a $63 million benefit for the quarter a year ago.
Operating expenses were $12 million whereas quarter-over-quarter as we estimated on our last call special maintenance expense was up $10 million quarter-over-quarter. The duration of planned outages were flat year-versus-year, but last yearâ€™s outages were related to tying in our scrubbers and as such more costs were capitalized.
As shown on slide #23, our 2010 special maintenance expense will also be higher in the fourth quarter compared to 2009, but will be lower for the full year. Moving back to the EBITDA summary, regulated operations benefited primarily from higher retail load, our transmission expansion projects and the West Virginia rate increase.
Our T&D retail revenue increased quarter-over-quarter driven primarily by $22 million related to load growth and favorable weather. Continued progress on TrAIL and PATH contributed to $19 million increase for transmission expansion. The West Virginia rate increase provided $10 million benefit. These results were partially offset by the effect of the sale of the Virginia distribution business.
Interest expense for the quarter was higher by $11 million primarily due to an $8 million increase in interest costs due to transmission expansion. About $4 million was due to the fact that we stopped capitalizing interest costs on the Hatfield scrubber project.
Depreciation increased by $10 million, primarily due to the Hatfield and Fort Martin scrubbers being placed in service in the second half of last year.
While not shown here, our effective tax rate for the quarter was approximately 34% compared to about 37% for the same period last year. The decrease is due primarily to a change in tax reserves.
Adjusted cash flow from operations was $304 million, a $42 million increase from the third quarter last year, and is due primarily to an increase in pre-tax income. Capital expenditures were $218 million, free cash flow, netting the securitization proceeds used to fund the Fort Martin scrubbers and financing for TrAIL was a positive $187 million for the quarter.
In aggregate, our liquidity, including cash balances, totals approximately $2.3 billion. In September, we increased the credit facility for TrAIL from $350 million to $450 million to finance forecasted increases in project costs. We have no remaining debt maturities through 2011, except for securitization and amortizations.
Now, letâ€™s turn to the outlook. Slide 27 summarizes our most recent estimate of the changes in EBITDA for each business and consolidated depreciation and net interest expense for 2010 compared to 2009.
Weâ€™re also reflecting changes in the 2010 outlook since the last call. The biggest change since the last call is in utility operations, and as I mentioned earlier, this was primarily due to increased load in weather.
For those of you who are thinking about the fourth quarter, Iâ€™d like to note significant items that benefited 2009 versus 2010 results. As shown on side 23, weâ€™ll have higher special maintenance expense versus the fourth quarter of last year. We had a $17 million pre-tax gain related to the purchase of a hydro facility last year.
Finally, we recognized an $18 million income tax benefit in the fourth quarter last year due to a change in the Pennsylvania tax law concerning net operating losses, which was an after tax benefit. Weâ€™ll now go through the drivers for 2010, highlighting items that have changed since our last call.
Moving to slide #28, for Merchant Generation, we estimate a $4 million decrease in 2010 EBITDA compared to 2009, which is an $8 million improvement compared to our estimate on the last call. Our estimates are based on among other things, forward power prices at September 30, 2010.
For the full year 2010, we are using a PJM Western Hub energy price of $45 per megawatt hour, which is the combination of nine months actual and three months forward prices.
You may recall that on our last call our estimates were based on forward prices of $46 per megawatt hour for 2010. Forward prices are subject to highly variable market factors and our estimates will continue to change due to fluctuations in those prices and other factors.
Realized energy prices for 2010 have not changed since our last call, but we have seen a decrease in volume of 1 million megawatt hours due to plant performance in the third quarter.
As I mentioned on the last call, one of our Hatfield units had a 26-day unplanned outage. Decrease in volume has contributed to a projected decrease in unhedged energy margin of $24 million. However, this should be more than offset by a projected increase in power hedge margin of $36 million.
Turning to slide #29, we are expecting to generate $7 million more megawatt hours than in 2009. We have generated $25 million megawatt hours year-to-date through September. Our estimated realized price for the year is $38 per megawatt hour.
We are estimating a $27 million decrease in coal expense compared to the last call, due primarily to decreased generation volume. $47 million increase in capacity reflects $22 per megawatt day increase in capacity prices.
Other net revenues include $30 million for our Kern River hedge which ends this year. So in summary, weâ€™re expecting our merchant generation unhedged EBITDA to be better by $108 million versus last year.
Adjusted EBITDA is calculated on slide #30 by starting with the unhedged EBITDA from the prior slide and adjusting for the impact of our power hedge position. These hedges include financial hedges, our West Penn PLR contract, which expires at the end of the year and other marketing contracts.
The projected margin contribution of our hedges has increased from our last call reflecting lower energy prices. In the appendix, we provide additional information for analyzing the business and some high level pre-tax income sensitivities.
Moving on to slide #31, utility operations; EBITDA for utility operations is now expected to increase by $8 million. This is $32 million better than our estimate on the last call.
As previously mentioned we experienced an increase in customer load due to weather and growth in the third quarter of $22 million. For year-to-date, weâ€™ve experienced an increase of $27 million.
Slide 32 shows estimated growth in rate base for utility operations. Please note that these are only estimates and our plans are always subject to change. Our rate base forecast reflects the capital expenditures associated with the smart meter plan we filed with the Pennsylvania Commission on October 19. This represents a substantial reduction in the rate base for 2010 and 2011 compared to what we showed you on our last call.
We have also included $360 million, primarily in the outer years in transmission projects approved through the PJM RTEP process. Weâ€™re increasing our estimate for 2010 transmission expansion EBITDA primarily based upon the accelerated timing of TrAIL capital expenditures in 2010. TrAIL is expected to be in service in mid 2011, PATH is expected to be in service in 2015.
The rate base in our transmission expansion business is expected to grow to about $2.4 billion by 2014. In TrAIL and PATH, we earn a return in this business as capital expenditures are made. In addition to TrAIL and PATH, our estimate includes $155 million in additional PJM approved RTEP projects that will be constructed in our transmission expansion business.
Forecast for 2011 has changed from our last call because weâ€™ve reduced the TrAIL rate base by deferred taxes to reflect the recent extension of bonus depreciation for federal income tax purposes. This would reduce the rate base at TrAIL but would provide a cash benefit to Allegheny of $200 million over two years.
At the consolidated level, depreciation expense will increase by $43 million in 2010 due primarily to the scrubbers going into service in the second half of 2009. Fort Martin scrubbers will increase depreciation expense, but will not affect earnings because this expense is recovered through a surcharge.
Our capital forecast is reflected on slide #36. Weâ€™ve included the $515 million of PJM RTEP projects that I mentioned earlier.
Moving back to the income statement, 2010 current estimated interest expense is $51 million worse than 2009. Remember net interest expense for transmission expansion is recovered in formula rates. The Hatfield scrubbers have been placed in service and interest that was previously being capitalized will now be expensed.
Finally, while not reflected here we expect our effective tax rate in 2010 to be about 37% which is a little lower than our long-term expected run rate of about 38%. Additionally, in our third quarter update, weâ€™ve provided a detailed outlook for the next year.
Given our focus on completing the merger with FirstEnergy early next year, weâ€™re not providing a detailed outlook for 2011. We have provided information regarding the rate base investment for our utility operations and transmission expansion and information concerning commodity prices and our hedging activities as well as other information.
With that Iâ€™ll turn the call over to the operator for questions.

So now that those coal reserves are more and inventories are back down to a normal level or even lower I think that puts a little pressure on spot prices.
